An excellent alternative to sodas.
This drink was pretty flat.  Pretty much tasted like cranberry juice with a tiny bit of bubbles.  I've had the bottled versions before (not of this flavor) and thought they were much better.
I absolutely love this elixir! It is refreshing and delicious as well as good for you.

I read about the benefits of pomegranate and I wanted something that was a little tart but refreshing, so I decided to try this drink. Boy, this beverage is great and with Subscribe & Save, I save money as well and free shipping also. I like it so much I decided to buy it twice a month. By the way I'm just a regular consumer and not affiliated in anyway with IZZE or Amazon.
These are my favorite of the fortified sparkling juice brands. The serving size is perfect. I saved both time and money having my IZZE delivered.

If you are used to Hawaiian Punch, Snapple, sugary Kool-aid, or other "fruity" drinks, you won't find the same high fructose corn syrup kick in this product. It actually tastes like real fruit juice...imagine that.

I'll admit I like sweet fake-fruit drinks as much as the next person, so my first few sips of Izze's pomegranate sparkling water made me question my selection. I had expected something more akin to lightly flavored water, but the taste was an overwhelming tartness.

I have learned to enjoy though and wish my parents had given me this as a kid so that my tastebuds would consider this "sweet". It is still a little strong and tart for me, so I mix it 1-to-1 with water. Diluted by half is still enough flavor for me, so each 12 once can actually doubles in size when I drink it.

Lastly, everything about the company suggests they will appeal to progressive-minded individuals, from their use of all natural products, their green endeavors (factories powered by wind) and their philanthropic operations.

I've been enjoying my Izze Pomegranate juice, and I'll tell you why:

1. It's crisp and refreshing. Since it is mostly fruit juice and carbonated water, the only sugar is naturally occuring in the juice.

2. It has 70% real fruit juice. The benefits of that are spelled out on the nutritional facts label. 10% of your daily vitamin C, B6 and niacin is in every can.

3. The absensce of high fructose corn syrup. That heavy, ubiquitous sugar substitute we find in nearly every processed food in America these days, especially in the soft drinks. Izze has none of that.

One gripe - The cans are small at 8.4 ounces. That usually leaves me wanting more. It's an encouraging sign that people are willing to eat food in small quantities like this, but making these closer to the size of a typical soda can and adding another 20-30 calories would be great.

*****
If you love bergamot (as I do) then this is your tea. Numi Tea is all high quality, and this aged Earl Grey is no exception. It is a strong, fine tea, and the bergamot is the star. I noticed that it has been mentioned here that the bergamot flavor is too mild; to me, the bergamot flavor is quite prominent, but I don't drink artificially flavored tea, so if you do, this might be a change for you. I love it and would not go back to fake bergamot for anything--real bergamot is a treat and hard to find. Over time, you really don't want anything else and the fake stuff tastes chemically. So if you want to try the real thing, I think you'll love this tea.

This tea is certified organic and contains just Organic Assam Black Tea TGFOP Grade 1 (Oxidized Camellia Sinensis) scented with organic Italian Bergamot Fruit (Citrus Bergamia). It is also kosher. On the box, the manufacturer writes: "Numi's special Earl Grey is oil-free, using a unique method of aging premium Italian bergamot fruit with malty Assam black tea. When brewed, it imparts an exquisite red-orange hue that calls to mind dawn's finest moments. Balanced and stunning, we've recreated this timeless classic."

The price is perfect, a nice savings over single boxes. If you like Earl Grey tea, get it---you won't be sorry.

Highly recommended.
*****

This tea has a smooth, well rounded flavor and goes very well with steamed milk. I drink tea all day, and Earl Grey is my go to black tea. Earl Grey is great black, and a bit of extra dark chocolate on the side is better. Nothing breaks a hot day, or tension like a good tea. This tea has an aroma that pulls. Of the many brands out there this is definitely in my top 5(like #4 or maybe 3), because of the consistency in flavor, good selection, and the company mantra doesn't hurt either. I generally let this tea steep much longer than other brands, because it just doesn't get bitter. My wife got me hook on Earl Grey lattes, and everyone I've offered it to. If you're looking to try something new or a different brand, Numi is well worth a try. And if you've never had the latte it's: a splash of hot water, tea, vanilla syrup (I like just a shot for 16 to 20 oz, but the amount's up to you), and fill with hot milk.

One of the reasons why I love Early Grey tea is the scent of bergamot oil and the strong black tea flavor. This tea, was no Earl Grey. It was more like Assam, with a hint of bergamot oil. If you like Earl Grey, I suggest you try Mariage Frères French Blue Earl Grey or Adagio's Earl Grey. If you like organic, try Mighty Leaf.
This is the best earl grey blend we have tasted so far.  Good enough we are on auto ship for it.

The tea is weak, without the slightest hint of bergamot scent or taste.  Even if it were plain black tea, it is of inferior quality. They make a big deal of their organic, wholesome, green image. It's all fancy marketing and packaging. I paid 8.99 for a box of 18 bags at a drugstore. I truly feel gypped.

I am sorry to say I found this tea very weak in flavor. I was very dissapointed in this tea, in fact I felt they
put more work in the packaging than they did the tea.

As you can see, I ordered a set of three boxes of these, happy for free shipping and a good price, which Amazon usually lacks on groceries... and how disappointed I was, not in Amazon but in Numi...

I guess too many complained that the SMELL wasn't like other EGs, and they're right... it wasn't. Others spray alcohol-containing, leaf-wrecking oils on the leaves, leaving behind a horrible taste to me and also making the leaves oxidize rapidly, making the tea quality suck! Numi HAD it absolutely perfect. I was ready to tell you how to get, out of their tea, the perfect GENUINE Earl Grey tea, one where the tea wasn't killed by modern techniques of spraying chemicals (essential oils are almost all alcohol, after all; bergamot oil is almost always mixed with cheaper and easier to process citrus that grows far more places than a tiny town in Italy)... and now, I'm just here to say "move along, nothing here to see" because in changing their fruit supplier or aging/malting process or -something- (the tea leaves wouldn't likely vary so much, the brews side by side making the same color and the leaves being cut the same way and clearly the same region and process--yes, I'm one of THOSE tea drinkers, Steepster reviews and all), from the bags smelling like another brand, a rather costly one that starts with R and nearly rhymes with fishy, which has rather funky EG (that brand sprays the leaves, which Numi proclaims my shared disdain for)... well, what was--back when they had the boxes with the old man and his walking stick slumped in front of a cottage or whatnot--the first and only EG I would drink happily, a tea I went to specific 24/7 restaurants at 2am when needing food just because I could at least count on the tea... well, it's a passing memory, one I have about half a dozen more memories to treasure before parting ways with Numi, probably with an email expressing sadness.

I DO overall recommend their teas: The lemon myrtle chamomile, now deceptively called lemon chamomile when it's the FLOWER not the fruit added to lovely organic chamomile, is hopefully still as wonderful, their Moroccan Mint is unsurpassed and the smoothest, sweetest mint imaginable, impossible to oversteep for that matter, able to handle a trio of steepings for that matter [whereas Stash uses PNW mint that is medicinal, which is honestly only good to make yogurt sauce or ... medicine!], and even for the ones like Golden Chai that aren't to MY liking, they're still well made, just not a blend I care for ingredient-wise...

I simply can't recommend THIS Numi product anymore (and I hope as I use the last of my others this proves the ONLY one that got "revamped" somehow, the "how" seemingly the fruit, whether they are doing it faster or using different fruit or outsourcing the bergamot processing or... whatever they changed to make it a stinky-bagged, fruitless flavored, bitter chemical-aftertaste tea). I tasted the new just one night after a week of delighting in their original blend night after night, using my reliable method with precise timing and all, went away from it a full month, and in finding the last half box of the old, decided to compare them to be sure it wasn't simply me being thrown off. It's not. I don't deem it so unworthy that it can't be a pleasant change for the people who benefit from our brunch outreaches geared at homeless populations, and it'll probably be a welcome addition, but I will NOT be drinking the other 51 bags from this purchase myself, not when I have teas I genuinely love (as I did this, which was barely drinkable with a LOT of sugar that rendered it barely-even-tea anymore--before, it was best with a tiny bit of sugar and milk, but it was absolutely palatable with no additions).
Although I love Numi teas, the flavor from the tea bags is very weak for aged earl gray. I will keep this first shipment though will look for a brand with more flavor.

This is one of the best Earl Grey teas on sale in the U.S., but all too often supermarkets don't even carry it, and when they do they tend to price it rather high. I placed a recurring order for 3 boxes per month and get it cheaper than I ever would in a store owing to the discount applied for multiple purchases (and no postage costs). The parcel arrives promptly each month and the process is trouble free. I'd recommend it to any tea connoisseur.
Love this tea. We tried other Earl grey teas. So far this is the very best. Love the fact that it is Organic, Fair Trade and more. You got to try it!

These are the small boxes of Juicy Juice. I love the small boxes. Kids can actually finish the box and I don't have to worry about spilled half juice boxes. The kids on my son's t-ball team seem to prefer the orange tangerine flavor. These go much quicker than grape and strawberry kiwi.
These are perfect for my little guy. They are the perfect size for him and I love that they are 100% juice.

These are great juice boxes. First: the Orange Tangerine is delicious and generally hard to find in grocery stores. Second: this size is PERFECT for little people. These juice boxes are as small as you are going to find - but that is the point right? The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends no more than 4-6oz of juice per day for children, so at 4.23 oz per box - you aren't loading them up with juice. We have these on subscribe and save, so always have them on hand when we are on the run. My kids love them for the flavor, and I love them for their size and 100% juice (no added sugar, additives) - a win for everyone!

Juicy Juice is always a hit in our family and with my students. Being 100% juice makes it a winner for school snacks and general meal accompaniment. This pack contained the 4 oz size, which is perfect for a quick refresher. Purchased through the Amazon Grocery Subscribe & Save feature, this product was perfectly affordable. When partnered with our Amazon Prime membership for free shipping, it cost less than our local grocer. Simply can't beat having a favorite treat delivered straight to your door for less! And what a fun afternoon...juice by mail! Thank you UPS and Amazon! Very pleased. Looking forward to our next shipment!

Somebody help me with my math -- either I'm off or Amazon is. I hope Amazon is because it means this juice is an even better bargain for our meetings. Anyway, here's what I get:

8 count boxes of 4.23-Ounce ea. = 33.84 oz.

5 Packs of 8 boxes or 5 X 33.84 = 169.2 oz.

5 boxes for $11.64 divided by 169.2 oz. = $0.0688 per oz.

Amazon shows $0.55 per oz.

My calculations showing these little boxes at 29 cents each is a bargain for some really good juice.
This is our favorite Matzo.  The Everything tastes like an everything bagel.  We like it year around with butter & salt.  The price on Amazon was far better than our grocery store too.
I was very pleased with my latest order of Biscotti.  I will definitely by this product again.  Everything arrived in perfect order.

I love these biscottis. They are 15 calories each and taste wonderful. Because there are so few calories these falls under a diet product which means they aren't cheap. However I got them here for about 30% less than the other vendor I used online.

According to the FDA, the reason for the recall was:
"The firm decided to recall the wheat flour products they repack that do not declare "wheat" on the finished product labels." ([...])
So there is really nothing wrong with the product itself and it should be rather obvious that Gluten Flour should contain wheat unless indicated otherwise....

Stored in the fridge, this product lasts for years, and remains insect free and ready to add to anything to which you wish to add extra body during the baking process.......this high quality gluten does a great job of trapping the bubbles of carbon dioxide produced by the yeast and your baked goods will rise much higher and be lighter to the taste.
The product seems satisfactory. My husband uses gluten in  the making of his whole wheat honey bread.
I like the resealable pouch.  It works well crumbled in soup.  I also add crumbles to miso.
great when you want something light; can take with you anywhere; lots of fiber; low calorie; perfect part of my diet; taste as good as the strawberry flavor

These are convenient for when I need to have something to eat and don't have time.  All I need are in the nutrients.  And my son thinks they are good.  He has been getting into them and drinking as fast as I do.

These smoothies are perfect for just grabbing out of the fridge and going. When I absolutely have to miss a meal or have to cut one short, having one of these keeps me going better than anything else I've tried. It keeps me full while at school or work and the amount of protein makes me feel good about having it as a post-workout shake.
Tastes great cold! Just shake it up and pound it after your workout and start recovery. I just ordered 8 cases! Not grainy or clumpy like other products.

I love these smoothies and feel that they are satisfying and healthy.  I am looking for other sources since I was buying mine at Costco and now they have discontinued them.  I think they had them in the wrong section.  They are a few dollars less at costco.

These shakes are delicious and filling. There are times I need something to hold me over until dinner and these shakes do the trick plus they help me keep my liquid intake up.  I usually drink half first thing in the morning and then another half later in the day.

This is the best protein shake out there, not only is it affordable but it tastes great. This is a great for work when i dont have time to eat lunch this will keep me full for hours. I would recommend this shake to anyone, and i love drinking this after a workout. You will not be disappointed.

I like the product and it does give you energy but the product is not all natural.

Ingredients
Purified water, whey protein isolate, blackberry juice, buleberry juice, rasberry juice, strawberry juice, papaya juicek, aleo vera leaf juice, fruit and vegetable juice, concentrate, sugar, soluble fiber, pectin, citric acid, natural and artifical flavors, guar gum, sucralose, ascorbic acid.

The artifical ingredients in the product are the sucralose, asorbic acid (manufactured in a laboratory Vitamin C) and the artificial flavors. I see no reason to have these in the product because it does contain a lot of fruit and sugar (8g)which is why I gave the product 4 stars.
Love this smoothie drink;Body Choice Orange Smoothie, 16-Ounce Bottles (Pack of 12) it keeps me feeling full for hours. I have now signed-up to have it delivered on a regular basis.
Love this product!  Perfect for school lunches for my little guy!  He loves it and the ingredients are wholesome.

I just tried this for lunch. It was pretty good for a gluten free item. If you are used to gluten free (or similar) food you will probably like this. If you not used to gluten free food then I don't know. The flavor was good. I like the size for myself, but if my husband were to eat it he may need 2+ packages for a filling meal. I really like that this product offers a portable, shelf stable food that I can have as a meal if I am on the road and do not have access to safe gluten free food. We have some trips planned for the summer and I plan to take these (and the other flavors) on all of my trips.

nice product, nice product worth every penny and i most definitely needed it for my diet. a purchase that you couldnt get a better price for. excellent product and a recommended buy for those fish eaters

I initially purchased a few varieties of the Bumble Bee Salad snack kits to take out deer hunting with me. I was looking for something easy to carry, didn't take up much room, was tasty, and would last for awhile without spoilage.

The kit comes with a 3 ounce can of tuna salad, 6 crackers, and a small plastic paddle to spoon the salad on the crackers. The tuna is in a metal can with a foil lid and the crackers are in a small cellophane (foil looking) pouch. The little plastic piece is just floating around in there.

After being carried and tossed around for a few weeks, I tore open a pack. The crackers did not hold up too well to the abuse and were mostly a stack of pieces and crumbs. The cardboard was splitting open allowing dirt to get inside, but at least the little plastic thing was still in there.

The taste of the salad was actually quite good. I did not think it had an overwhelming fishy smell which could be beneficial if you are eating it in close quarters to others who might not like fish. There is more than enough salad for the crackers which is a nice surprise as most snacks seem to make you ration the spread.

If you are on a diet, this meager snack is definitely not worth the 300 calories. If you are looking for something portable to take on the road, hiking, fishing, hunting, or a snack to send to a soldier in the field, this is a handy, self contained snack. If the packaging was a bit more durable to protect the crackers, I would say this would be pretty close to the perfect field snack.

J. E. Nelson
Quick filler-up if your on the go when your in a hurry to be some where, just open, slap and eat... BAM!!

Samsclub sell this like $10, much better price, this is great for office use, when you want something quick without need of microwave.  Wish it has napkins, it does has folk, couple piece of craker, the tuna salad itself is delicious, try to eat like 2 of them same time, it has has some fat on it.

Millet flour is great for my gluten free recipes (just remember the xanthan gum). This company takes a little while for shipping and the shipping is a little high, but, the products they sell are cheaper than anywhere else with a greater variety offered.

I was happy to find Avena smoothies available in the US, as it is a delicious, smooth and nutritious drink that blends oats and milk. The Tetra pack with straw makes it perfect at home, for school lunches or on the go. It can be drunk by the glass, in cereal, or as a snack. The long expiration date (about 6 months without refrigeration) is a big plus. It is made in the USA and distributed directly by the manufacturer, Alpina Foods, out of Miami FL.

That said, I was surprised at the ingredients: water, sugar, powdrered milk, oat flour, mono & diglycerides, carragenan, guar gum, xhantan gum, salt, sodium tripolyphosphate. In terms of nutrition: 180 calories, 4 grams of fat (3 are saturated), 10 mg cholesterol, 115 mg sodium, 22 gr sugar, 1 gr fiber, 5 gr protein, Calcium 16 DV%. While it tastes similar to real avena, the overly processed ingredients give me pause. I will be looking for a recipe for real avena which is probably not that hard to make and a lot healthier.

As a sidenote, you can buy this at your local supermarket (in the section of south american foods) in 8 oz containers for half the price.

This is so far my favorite flavor of all of the Ramune flavor I have tried.

It has a fun look to it and is great for those who love sweet drinks and don't like or drink caffeine.

I being one who avoids caffeine when possible was excited to find a drink I could add to me fridge to give me a change from the few caffeine free drinks I can tolerate.

I would recommend these to anyone. If nothing else you have to try at least one in your life time.

I bought the melon flavor for myself and this strawberry for my father. I was surprised that I really liked the melon, and my father had a great time opening the bottle of his strawberry. He's the type who HAS to know how things work, so after finishing the drink he went about taking apart the top of the bottle! Plus, he said that it "was a pretty good drink", which is a good compliment from him.

We enjoyed the drinks quite a bit, and the bottle made an interesting conversation topic. I'm sure that kids would love this.
When I got these, I was so excited. They were great, except one thing. Make it cold before drinking. It does not taste good warm.
Before buying this, I was unsure of what it would be. When I tasted it it was very sweet a little too much for my liking. Others may find it appealing, but only $1.99. Go ahead and try it

Not sweet and syrupy like US sodas. Very refreshing with only 90 calories per 6.76 oz.  Bottle (7% carbs). Zero sodium, fats and cholesterol. The weird glass bottle is a hoot. No plastic bottle aftertaste.

Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin food was a big hit with my dog. It has a variety of pieces, meat and vegetables, soft and crunchy. It has big chunks that are meant to emulate real pieces of beef. My dog seemed to especially like those. He took each piece out of the bowl and chewed it up in the same manner he would eat a big piece of meat. When I first put some of this food in his bowl, he ate it up in no time and came sniffing around the bag for more. He's a big dog and eats a couple of good sized scoops of dry food each day, so this 4.5 pound bag lasted less than a week. It would last longer for a smaller dog and I'll buy a bigger bag next time I get some.

The only thing I don't like about this dog food is the bag. It has to be cut open, which is slightly less convenient than just ripping it or pulling on a string, but not a big deal. I also wish the bag were resealable with a Ziploc-type closure. I have to either transfer this food to another container once opened, or fold it up just so and push the open end against the wall to keep it shut. The bag, however, is not a deciding factor when I'm looking for a food my dog enjoys. I'll certainly consider this dog food in the future.

My dog was and I repeat a WAS a Beneful eater.  However, I decided to try this brand and he loves it.  I have also purchased the chicken dry dog food.  The food is light and he can easily chew it.  There is a difference in price, the Chef Michael's brand is about $4 more than the Beneful bag at my local Shoppers.  But the higher cost is worth it for his enjoyment.

My foster doxies gobbled this food right up. It arrived at the perfect time for one of them; he had been picking at his regular food and generally not feeling well, we found out he was having problems with a tooth and this softer dog food was perfect for him. Now that he's better, he still prefers it. I was happy that the first ingredient was beef, not beef by-product. My only concern is that it has food dyes, Red 40 and more, I know that there are organic vegetable dyes like beet juice that might be better for them. They've eaten half a bag in the last 2 weeks and no adverse effects. Good job Chef Michael.

My thirteen year old mixed breed Lady loved this food from the moment we first put it in her bowl.  Typically she does not eat all of her food at one time but grazes through out the day.  She ate this each time it was put out in one single feeding.  For her it was a meal that was a treat.  Will be looking at purchasing other Chef Michael.

I wanted to try this Chef Michael's for a while so when it came I put Chef Michael's in one bowl and Beneful in the other.  Well, pretty much all three would sniff the Beneful then walk over to Chef Michael's and start eating.  The food itself didn't look too much different than regular dog food but the dogs (all three) seem to enjoy it.  They have been pretty quiet as too how much....but they finished the whole bag.  ha ha ha

Our dog Snowball just ~loves~ Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin, and he will make a point of nosing around in the bowl to eat the "meaty bits" first, and then finish off the rest.  He's a fairly picky eater, but this has certainly been one of his favorites.  Our local grocery store isn't carrying this (yet) so this is one purchase for which Amazon Prime shipping will come in quite handy.

Our dog rarely eats her entire bowl of food at one time.  She usually eats a little and returns to it throughout the day.  That all changed as soon as I tried this food.  She quickly consumed the entire bowl when I poured it in.  In addition, she is more eager than ever for her food when I reach for this bag.  This has been surprising to me since I was sure dog food is dog food is dog food.  However, it is clear that this dog food is much preferred by our dog at least.

This dog food is palatable according to my dogs.
Taking a closer look.

Pros :
Beef is the first ingredient
23 vitamins and minerals
100% complete nutrition for adult dogs
protein 28%
fat 16%
fiber 3%
water 12%
No added artificial preservatives.

Cons :
Ground Wheat (Wheat Gluten)
Added Color _ Red Dye 40

I mention these as some of my cats are allergic to Red Dye 40 and some dogs can become allergic as well as to corn and soya.

Tender pieces (The Beef Part)with crunchy kibbles (The Died Vegetable Part)
Moderately more expensive than the average dry dog food but worth it for a finicky eater. The primary protein is chicken.

I'm really torn on this dog food because I know my dogs really like it but i also know it really isn't filled with the best stuff for the animal. When i put it down my dogs went through the process of devouring it, treating it like a snack and not like food, and that was a good sign. They really liked it. I do try to give them treats now and again and give them at least decent food, but this was well beyond what they were accustomed to. That got me thinking whether this was the best thing for them or not and, reading the bag, I decided it wasn't. The ingredients read like a laundry list of items my vet says to avoid, and I don't think that's the greatest thing to feed them all the time.

I guess the best thing to say on this is that it would be a superb addition to the diet of the animal, given that you did not use it as a main item. As a supplement, my dogs would love it and anything they love loves me back. since it did not clump or show any signs of being cheaper food that makes it great too, and the price really isn't bad. This was a trial bag, but i am going out to pick some up and use it when I think the dogs really deserve something they will savor.

Thanks.
My pug is kind of picky but she really took to the Chef Michael's sirloin dry kibble' I gave it to her mixed with her usual kibble and we had no problem with digestive upset.

I don't really know how to review dog food other than to say my Cocker Spaniel Bonnie is a finicky eater and she just gobbles this up. Sometimes I wish she could talk. However, if she could, I have a feeling she'd be telling me she loved, loved, loved this dog food. Or maybe in the words of a dog food commercial from yesteryear, she'd say it was, "Doggone good!"
Judging by the way the dogs eat this food, they love it.  We also put some in a small container and are using the nice size bites as treats.

There are surely some tasty morsels in Chef Michaels Grilled Sirloin Dog Food and there are a few things which my dog wants nothing to do with. My 11 year old dog is pretty set in what she likes and does not like. She is about as discerning as a dog can be. She might have some cat in her as far as her taste buds go because she can be very picky. My dog, LueLue seems to pick some bits out and chow them down pretty fast and leaves alot lying all around her bowl. Then she also does that dog thing where she leave a little trail. I though this would be a good change for her but I can see that we are headed back to Beneful.

Okay, I have a black lab that will eat almost anything...she rejects green peas, banana peels, most fruit and most trash.  I feel that it is important to tell you that, as she aids significantly in this review.  With that said, she does seem to really like this food.  We are pleased and will definitely consider it in the future.  I have no clue what a finicky dog's verdict would be.  This bag is a good size for a trial run though and there isn't a shelter out there that couldn't use the unused portion if you Fido decided it wasn't up to his standards.  Daisy liked it!

I concur with the majority of the reviews here: my dog seems to quite like this food. It feels a bit moist, looks somewhat colorful, and even smells a bit of beef. In other words, it certainly comes across as good-quality dog food. However, it's worth noting that the ingredients seem to be somewhat of a mixed bag.

Beef is the most prevalent ingredient, which indicates a slightly higher quality of product. Look at the labels of many other bags of dog food, and you'll see that the first ingredient is usually some filler -- unfortunately, fillers seem to take up several of the succeeding slots on the ingredients list of this Chef Michael's product. So it's certainly not the highest quality you'll find, but it's definitely not the worst either.

Bottom line, my guess is that it seems to be a bit higher quality than your average bag of dog food, and that makes it a bargain for the price. You could do better if you're willing to pay for it, but I think this food will do well for most dog owners.

Our dogs have been eating chicken and rice for quite some time now, but they have no problem when I put some Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin in their bowls. They eat it right up. They seem to look eager when I'm crinkling the bag for the next serving as well.

My dog is really picky about what dry food she'll eat. It was only because I trusted the brand so much that I was willing to give it a try and I am happy I did.
Daisy has liked the food since her very first bowl - I didn't have to mix it with her old food and try to sneak it to her - really unusual for her.
I like the different sized pieces that are in the bag because the shapes seemed to make her eat more slowly, they probably cleaned her teeth good, and she seemed to get full on less food than what I was giving her before.
So far we have only tried 1 bag and part of a second but there have been no health issues and my trust in the Purina brand has paid off.

Since I feed my dogs Science Diet (recommended by my vet), I've been giving this to them as 1/4 of their regular meal.

Honestly, they really do enjoy the taste and often times will finish this food before their regular food. Using it as a snack or 1/4 of their meal, they have not had any stomach upset.

There are dry kibble bits along with a more moist kibble.The more moist parts are flakes which seem elastic and rubbery.

It has a savory scent which just calls them to the dinner bowl. You can separate the moister bits and keep them as reward or treats, another tip given by my vet.

My dogs loved this food. I wasn't surprised that the younger liked it. Her name should be Kirby. Our older dog is a bit more picky, but seemed to really enjoy the food.

As a pet owner, I'm not very fond of it. I think it's a bit pricy, especially for the amount. Also, I don't think it's good for them, too much soy, corn and added colors. I read somewhere that dogs really can't see colors so why was it necessary to add colors, especially since some dogs don't react well to color dyes.

Even though my dogs enjoyed it, I won't be switching from our regular brand.

I try to feed Maggie quality food because she is a valuable member of my family.  This food was great, I loved the mea tand vegeatble chunks and so did she.  She was getting to the point that she wouoldn't eat Iams or Science Diet and now I can mix this in with it and she eats it.  The only complaint I have is that noe of the local stores carry it.

I am not going to get into the nutritional side of this product because Brenda has done an outstanding job of covering that. The woman knows her dog food! I am simply going to tell you our dogs opinion of the taste quality:

Beckham is a two year old whippet who is more pup than dog. He typically eats Purina One for meals, meaty bones and pigs ears for snacks and a denta-bites for his teeth. His breeder (who I am sure was glad to see the backside of Beckham) recommended the above, well, okay not the pigs ears but that is just so deliciously disgusting to impose on the kids. Beckham has also been known to eat grass, slugs, deer poo and other revolting items. What Beckham will not eat is Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin. Said Sirloin has been hand fed to Beckham, hidden in with his standard kibble and offered as a treat for not pulling on walks. Nope, nope, nope, Beckham is not having it. Chef Michael please report back to the kitchen.

Not recommended by Beckham. (Or Brenda)

I help care for pets when their owners leave town. As I never know when I will be expected to take in a furry visitor I like to keep a bag of kibble on hand. I picked up a bag of Chef Michael's for a couple of reasons:

1.) Nutritionally it has a good generic base for any Dog: 28% crude protein (beef), 16% crude fat (min), 3% Crude fiber (max) and toutes 23 essential vitamins and minerals. (like the dog notices.) It's a good mix of both tender & crunchy bits.

2.) I admit I picked it up on sale and the shelf-life is for well past a year.

However, my wards have yet to turn their nose up at it and it goes down well.

It's a little hard to write a review on a product that you don't actually use yourself. I thought I would get this and give it a try as my dog has been off his food for a little while now. I've tried various different dogfoods to see which one he liked to no avail.
The first thing you notice when you open the pack is the amount and quality of the steak in the food. I gave a bowl to my dog and he went through the whole bowl in about 10 minutes and was begging for more. Finally a product that he'll eat and one that won't break my bank either.

Some of the other reviewers have gone into great detail about the nutritional content of this, as well as the price difference. Not only is there no need for me to repeat it all, I don't think I could do it justice as they had.

What I can do is agree with them - the dogs really like this. But the dogs don't know what's good for them, and they don't know when to stop. Our dogs have been on rationed food in order to keep them trim and fit. One of them, a labradoodle, scarfs up the food so fast that she has to have her small portions doled out to her in smaller portions. And even then it seems half of it must go into her lungs since she's inhaling, not eating. This made it even worse.

As others have said, it's like candy for dogs compared to the other foods out there. And while the dogs seem to really love it, the owners have to be the ones in control, and use common sense. For a regular diet, I just don't see the content this offers as matching up to some of the better designed foods out there for pets. Let's face it - in the multi-billion dollar pet industry, there's MORE than enough choice out there to find what's the best content and at a reasonable price. I just don't think this is the answer for our dogs.

My elderly (16 y.o.!) chow-shepard-lab mix loooooooves this food.  She will eat hers at blinding speed, then horn in on our other dog's bowl - and she never violates the "food bowl territory" of the other dog.  Considering the older dog was losing her appetite and losing weight (along with eyesight and hearing, sigh!) we are overjoyed that we've found a food she's willing to dig into. For this reason alone, I would give the product 5 stars, as I think her interest in the food may help her live a bit longer (i.e., she's putting on weight, which is a good sign - she used to weigh 48lbs, and had dropped to 37!).  That said, our chow-beagle mix, who is 7 y.o., absolutely hates the food.  I pour it into her bowl and she looks at me forlornly, sighs, then walks off into the yard in protest. I'm not sure she eats it at all (I think our older dog is eating both), which is why I'm also giving the younger dog other dog food/biscuits as a supplement.  Based upon my gratitude to Purina for creating a dog food my elderly dog loves, I'm giving the food 4.5 stars.  It would have been 5 if only I could get our other dog to eat it, too!

I so wanted to post a video of our dog eating Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food, but my camera software would not cooperate.  I will therefore provide you a written testimony.  Shep, our rescued English Setter, has always been very finicky about his food.  Many times he walks away rather than eat something he does not care for.  Upon seeing Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food in his bowl he took the time to fully investigate by sniffing and lightly tasting with his tongue and then drooling (Shep has a tendency to do that when he really likes something).  Then, he started eating and he ate and he ate, until it was all gone.  Then, like one of the three bears he examed his empty bowl numerous times in the hopes that more would appear.  He repeated this ritual with every meal until the bag was gone.  We're on our way to the store now to refill his pleasure palate.  I can highly recommend this dog food.

I know that most dog foods are designed to appear appetizing to the dog's owner. This one certainly appears that way. The smell is pleasing, and it actually looks like a meal. Ok, not a meal that I would eat, but it looks like a meal rather than kibble. With that said, my dogs went wild for this stuff. I have a collie and a pointer/lab. The pointer is the more aggressive when it comes to eating, and the collie, while older and larger, usually waits his turn at the bowl. The moment I poured this bag into the bowl, the collie took over and the pointer was relegated to grabbing a mouthful and absconding to the other room to enjoy it.

Needless to say, it costs a lot more than dog chow, and at this price they won't be getting it often, but this sure was a nice treat for the dogs!

For a dry dog food this has dog appeal.
The test dog is off dry in these hot summer days,
but she dug right in to a big serving
and it was gone in a few moments.
That reaction puts this dog food high
on the customer satisfaction scale.

Our dog grew up on Purina products and trust the name, so we were eager to try this food out on him. When I removed the bag from the box, our dog was eagerly sniffing it and seemed to be excited about the contents. When it was opened, he began to act like he does when we get his dog treats out, hopping around and begging for it. He couldn't wait for it to be poured in his dish and gobbled it right down. Unlike his normal Dog Chow that is left to eat when he is hungry, this has to be rationed or I really don't think he'd stop until it was gone. Instead we sprinkle it over top of his regular food and dole it out like a treat. He has no problems digesting Chef Michael's unlike the Purina Beneful Original, 7-Pounds we tested on him a while ago.

From our dog's point of view this food was "totally awesome"!

I gave this food to my parent's dogs (country dogs that run around outside all day - a Blackmouth Cur and a Pitbull/Heeler mix). Both of them absolutely loved it and ate it a lot faster than they normally eat their food (especially the Cur). In fact, she had to eat hers a lot faster or the Pit would have been moving in on her bowl. Usually these two dogs eat their food next to each other, maybe a little bit of snapping or trying to eat each other's food but not too much. They were crazy for this stuff and more excited than usual to eat the next day. That's a really good thing if you have a dog that is finicky but maybe not so good if you have more than one dog and one of them might want to try stealing the other's food. I don't think this is the healthiest food choice but it's definitely something that dogs enjoy and is a perfect treat (or something to mix in with other foods to get them to eat it).

The dogs like it, as the other reviewers have said, but it doesn't seem to be a very good food for them. I wouldn't have gotten it if it hadn't been provided freely for review through the Vine program. The advertising sounds good but...

Here are the GA numbers:

Crude Protein (min.) 28.0%
Crude Fat (min.) 16.0%
Crude Fiber (max.) 3.0%
Moisture (max.) 12.0%
Linoleic Acid (min.) 1.2%
Calcium (Ca) (min) 1.0%
Phosphorus (P) (min.) 0.8%
Vitamin A (min.) 14,000 IU/kg
Vitamin E (min.) 150 IU/kg

Those are actually decent if not great GA figures. I think, though, that this food is a pretty good example of how to finesse GA numbers. Everything after 'beef' is mostly hard too digest filler material. Soy [except for soy hulls] is a rapidly fermenting fiber which means it doesn't do a very good job of absorbing water while being digested so the doggie may experience a laxative effect and end up with diarrhea. Yuk. My two dogs haven't seemed to have had that problem but I mixed this 4.5lb bag with about 3 pounds of very high quality food (small/regular breed version): Blue Buffalo Large Breed Wilderness Chicken Adult Dry Dog Food, 24 lbs.

It contains 'poultry by-product meat' which means the carcas minus the feathers. So, head, feet, gristle, etc. 'Animal digest' - google it for an eye opening description at wiki and then the other side of the story from Purina. Although Purina gives a pretty nice sounding description and I'm sure that the nutritional information is accurate, they actually confirm what wiki reports by way of ommission if nothing else. Purina can't be ignorant of what detractors say about this ingredient.

The big chunks that are red to represent beef are soft. So if you use dry food because you avoid soft food for your dogs you won't care for this even if it is otherwise not a problem for your situation.

I recommend looking for something else. The Blue Buffalo I linked is excellent but expensive.

I got this as a special present for a good friend and neighbor's Jack Russell and it did score big with both dog & owner.  Some reviewers attack it on nutritional grounds, but hey, I doubt it hurts giving this to a loved dog as a special treat from time to time.

Usually I mix my labs' dry dog food with wet in order for them to eat it. When I served them the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food, they licked their bowls clean. They didn't wait for me to add the wet food. The food has a colorful mixture of dry food with what looked like chunks of meat. My dogs and I highly recommend this brand!
Well, what can you say about dog food in a product review? My dog loved it... 'nuff said. It has a nice "meaty" look to it and, were I a k9, I believe I would enjoy the food as well :)

My dog eats anything and I mean literally, anything...oranges, grapes, spinach, watermelon...but not french fries or any form of potato (weird, I know!).
So, I wasn't surprised that he loved this.
We by Annamaet dog food so, of course, we are particular about what we feed our dog.
I decided to mix this in with his regular food as an extra bonus/treat and he absolutely loved it.
I didn't notice any sort of smell that others complain about and believe me, I am quite sensitive to smells.
No complaints here.

The ingredients list on this is decent...first ingredient listed is beef. There are still a lot of fillers (grains and meals) and several vitamins with 28% crude protein. My test doggie liked it...didn't love it. She wasn't sure at first about some of the pieces...set them aside and ate them later (she's not a picky eater).

I prefer the Cal Ranch high protein dog food for an active dog (44% protein). It costs way less too. For dogs who do fine on most anything I'll just stick with Dog Chow...I can't see a difference with "higher quality" dog foods for most of my dogs. Only the sled dogs/very active dogs and dogs with trouble keeping weight on seem to do better with higher protein foods. Less active dogs just get fat on them. I do supplement with a good amount of raw meat and fresh fruits/vegetables. Something like this may be good for dogs who don't get good supplements to dry food.

We've been trying out some cheaper options for dog food - the overly granola-y stuff from the upscale dog store was getting too expensive. I want something with a primary ingredient of meat, since, well, he's a dog, so I figured this would be a good option.

Pros:
- Soft, meaty bits, along with some bits that are crunchy to add variety.
- Dog piles into this one. He's a 3 year old Brittany and loves this food. Much better than the Costco stuff we tried before.
- The ingredients list doesn't read like a confusing blast of petrochemicals.

Cons:
- None, really. The bag's a bit small, I guess.

Of course she liked the taste - it's basically junk food for dogs.  I just can't get past the ingredients.  I won't be feeding this to my dog.  It's a cheap, low-quality food and I love my dog and want to give her better.  If you want to feed your dog a quality food, find something else.

Clean plate

Our dog is a medium size mixed breed that normally eats part of her food and then comes back later. We feed her 1 cup in the morning and 1 in the evening. Normally when we have switched foods there are some digestive upsets, but that did not happen with this brand.

More than that she sat and ate it all when she was served. The dog food we normally give her has beef as its first ingredient and so does this. The only problem is that this is more pricy and the bag has no closure, so especially for a food she will search out, it has to be put in a metal container, which we normally do, but the bag does not stay closed. We had to resort to taping it shut twice a day - it would be nice, especially for the price if there was a zipper like closure.

I cannot recommend this dog food.

Why? because it contains poultry by-product meal. I never give my dogs any dog food that contain by-products. By-products are essentially the left over beaks, tails, etc. from animals that companies don't know what to do with, so they grind them up and call them dog food. In addition, this contains ground wheat, and I've learned from past experience that wheat contributes to arthritic symptoms in some dogs. I also don't like the "grilled steak flavor" which is obviously artificial flavoring and has nothing to do with meat. That's how they can get away with saying this dog food has "grilled sirloin steak flavor."

I am sorry to give a poor review. I hate giving bad reviews. But some of the ingredients in this dog food are just sub-par. Sorry Nestle' Purina - I know for a fact that you make other quality products, but this isn't one of them.

This dogfood is like candy to the dogs, they love it, but it is not necessarily safe or healthy.  The soy protien in this food gives them horrible gas. It's not just irritating for the owner, (I mean I have my dog on my lap all the time) but serious can be detrimental to your dogs health gas.  Yes, they will gobble it up and beg for more, but I decided it was not good for my two small dogs.  As many other reviewers have already renumerated in more detail the reasons why this is just not good, I won't say more.  But I am very picky about what I give my dogs.  They are part of my family, and if there is a hint of doubt I won't give it to them.  The gas thing cannot be good.  Purina is a reputable company, so use your own judgement, this is just my opinion.

I have two dogs, a German Shepherd and a Beagle.  They absoluey love this Grilled Sirloin. In order for them to chew it without devouring and not swallowing it, I mix it with their regular dry food. Calms them down a bit. It's not crunchy, it's softer dry food. Very moist. They had no adverse reactions to it either; no diarrhea etc.

When I recently tested PURINA Beneful Original Dog Food on my dogs for another review, they dug around for the chewy/meaty pieces, and acted like savages with their dog feeder; I thought they would do the same thing with this dog food, but it was the green veggie-pieces that they dug out of the dog dish. Eventually they ate all of the pieces, but I was happy to see them take to the veggie ingredients over the meaty pieces.

The change in their diet didn't seem to have negative affects to their overall health or their potty habits; if anything, they seemed to have more energy than usual, although they are naturally bouncy dogs.

I would consider giving them this food again, if I could get them to stop digging for the green pieces first.

Amber, our Golden Retriever, ate this food right up.  She gave it 5 stars and said it was delicious.  We noticed that the food is "puffed up."  That's neither good or bad, just an observation.  I suppose if you have limited storage space, it would be an issue.  The food we normally give her is definitely more compact, and less airy.

When I receive new products for Muffin I always worry she won't like them, she is a pretty picky eater. Well, from the first bite she has loved this food. She is a smaller dog (Peek-A-Poo) but she has no problem chewing on the larger chunks. I mixed it with her old brand of food so the change would not be too drastic. She was so funny because she picked out all the new stuff and left the old in the dish. I guess that she has made her choice, I will be purchasing this from now on. I am also pretty impressed with the price, it is comparable to what she currently eats, and as always, Amazon offers the free shipping.

Dixie, our golden retriever, who's usually a picky eater, gobbles up the Purina Chef Michael's Dog Food" in seconds. She seems to love the smell, taste and texture of the grilled sirloin steak flavors and potato and green bean garnishes.
The 4.5 pound Chef Michael's package label says it ensures the adult dog food has 100% complete and balanced nutrition. The ingredients is real beef as the protein and vegetables as garnishes. The tender beef pieces and crunchy kibbles include twenty-three essential vitamins and minerals and no artificial preservatives.
Dixie and I wholeheartedly recommend the Chef Michael's dog food for a well-rounded, tasty meal with premier ingredients.

Length:: 1:52 Mins

This food was well recieved by my dog. However, on closer inspection...
Beef is the main ingredient. However, soy, wheat, and corn are in there, bumping out the amount of meat by quite a bit. Dried beans and potatoes are nice, but why the artificial color? The shame of it is, there are some really fine and healthy ingredients, but to make the cost something most folks are willing to pay, there are corners cut. As an occasional mix-in, this might be ok, but honestly, after reading the label, I wish they used better ingredients and charged a bit more. I certainly would not feed this on a regular basis.

Very pleased with the quality and ingredients listed. The two dogs really love this. It's nice to have found a food that they are happy with. Quality food, good price. They're happy--we're happy. Would definitely recommend giving it a try.

We have a Saint and two Chihuahuas and all three love the taste of this stuff. At the moment while breaking them in on this while keeping with their regular diet, we have been giving it to them as a treat. They love it. I am not sure you can give dog food a better review than that.

My dog gives this 2 big paws up.  Now, to be fair, he likes almost any food, but I think I detected, if possible, an even greater enthusiasm than normal for this one.  When he had gobbled it up, he sniffed all over to see if possibly there might have been a crumb dropped anywhere, and then came to me to see if perhaps I felt like giving him an extra helping.  And, not that it matters, but this food does look fancier than the normal dog food I feed him, with some of the kibbles resembling hunks of meat.  I was also impressed that the first ingredient was beef, although there was also lots of other stuff that was nowhere near natural.  I would also say that the softness of the beef-look kibbles is probably not great for his teeth, but maybe that's not a problem for you if you brush your dog's teeth.  But definitely for taste, attractive look, and beef content, I give this a high rating.

I don't own a dog, but I do have friends who do. They own a small, fluffy white dog of a nonspecific variety named Momo. He was a stray, so they don't know how old he is, but he's clearly getting up there in years. I know they want to take good car of him, so when the chance came up to snag them a quality dog food, I did so. They fed him some of the food the other day.

According to my friends, Momo initially turned up his nose at the food, and walked away. About twenty minutes later, he came back and started chowing down. He ate, according to them, far more than he usually does. They also commented that they personally liked the fact that it "looked like" real food.

So there you go. Momo the dog likes the food, and his owners are pleased by it, too.

I perfectly understand that the marketing of pet products is directed to the pet owner. I have never actually had a pet demand a certain brand of pet food-- I do have cats who refuse to eat pate style cat food, which I think may be my own fault for giving in to them and buying the sliced bits in gravy when they turned their little kitty noses up at the pate.

But anyway, the dogs definitely had a way of eating this dog food. The bits that represented steak went first. The last bit was the green things-- which is kind of amusing because I once had a dog who absolutely refused to eat the green round things in Beneful. She would delicately pick out all of the green things and leave them scattered around her bowl. So when I found the green things from this brand scattered around I wondered if Lucy's ghost had shown up to protest. Shortly after that I noticed that one of the dogs had finally eaten them.

No one developed any stomach problems or itchies after eating it so it has a thumbs up from a human and pricked ears from three dogs.

This dog food ( dry kibble) is. So popular with our dogs! and it is practically
odorless, so we can keep a bowl in our bedroom for nighttime snacking, which keep our dogs quite all night.

Dogs liked it "okay." Did NOT give it th the dogs on restricted diets (I have a Scottie and a Golden that have allergies). And the price point is high for the grade of food that this is. At this price point, you can get a food with less wheat and soy. And, one that dogs LIKE better. Dislike. (O, and this has red dye.)

I recommend [...] for finding a quality food (and the best quality fr your price range).

I had both of my golden retrievers try the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food to see if they would like it. The 8 month old overgrown puppy will eat almost anything and he loved this dog food, which I expected him to do. I wasn't so sure about the 9 year old "picky" eater, but she really liked this food, as well! She will eat her regular dry kibble, but not until she is really hungry, and she will often skip one of her twice daily feedings after checking to see what is in her food bowl. The morning she found Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin in her dish, she sniffed it, looked at me (I'm pretty sure she smiled) and proceeded to gobble up the food. Of course her "brother" had already inhaled his and was hoping for more!
This dry food is not shaped like regular kibble, in that every piece does not look or feel the same. The best way I can describe it is to say that it looks like "dehydrated" beef stew. The pieces of meat are irregularly shaped and flatter than most kibble, and the veggies (mainly peas and carrots) really look like vegetables. I would describe the texture as thick, solid "flakes" rather than round or square pieces of kibble. I detected no odor, although it must smell wonderful to the dogs.
I have not used the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin for the dog's regular feedings as one dog is still eating puppy food and the other eats senior formula, so I can't really comment on the nutrition value, or how this food affects their canine digestive tracts. What I can comment upon, is how much both dogs loved this food. I've been using a handful at a time as "training rewards" and both dogs like the Chef Michael's food as much as their regular treats. We can keep the dogs' regular bags of food on a closet floor to which the dogs have full access, but I've had to hide the Chef Michael's food, since I found a large golden head in the bag! A 4.5 bag is not going to last very long at our house.
I plan to discuss the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Food with my vet before feeding it to the dogs on a regular basis, but if she oks it, I will definitely purchase this dry food and add another star to my rating. (Hopefully, it is also sold in a 20lb or 40lb size). Until then, I'll use it as treats for the dogs, or for "dessert" on top of their present food. If my "picky dog," who often refuses regular dog treats, eats Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food, it's obviously yummy!

I have a finicky Border collie/Golden Retriever cross, and he's been tired of Science Diet, so I tried out Chef Michael's.

He likes it a *lot*. So, rank that as a plus. He seems to like this brand more than any other dog food brand.

On the minus side, he's smelling a bit weird now, on occasion. He's usually odor free 24/7, so that's a change for him. I'll see if that phases passes, and if it does, I'll stick with Chef Michael's. Obviously, that's what my dog would like, but I can be finicky, too.

Recommended.

It really looked like a bowl of stew.  My dogs seemed to scarf it down, which was a relief.  My wowser, jack, only ever seems to eat blue without me having to dress his food up with grated meat or cheese.  Pepper will eat anything so it didn't surprise me that she enjoyed this just as much as blue or nature's choice.

This food smells good, compared to a lot of dog foods, has beef, soy, potatoes & corn in it, but ell liked. My cat likes the little pieces (I'll have to do something about that to be sure it'k OK that she's eating to fog food, or put it up or something?)

Not at all "kibble". Looks like shredded jerky with smaller little bits in green & tan (I'm guessing soy & corn or soy & potato?)

Well liked & disappears quickly! (practically inhaled!)

The dog loves it & the cat even likes the smaller crunchy bits. Smells better than most pet food I've tried!

If your dog likes beef, they'll love this! I was even tempted to try a bit it looked really good! Has added vitamin E & others for coat & intestinal tract. I'm not a vet, & don't know a lot about dog digestion, but this is a FAR cry from those round balls of who knows what. Looks & smells like real beef jerky (might even be?)

Very well tolerated (both the dog & the cat like it!) Seems it would be easily digestible, as long as your dog digests beef OK.

Does contain soy, and I'm guessing quite a bit, which is why I gave this 4 stars as soy that isn't fermented (along with most nuts) contains enzyme inhibitors which can be deactivated by soaking (such as with soaking almonds that BTW taste a LOT better that way!) or fermenting, which I doubt s done in the dog food, so I would investigate that further, as soy beans & nuts (at least in humans & from reading, apparently in dogs too) can reduce thyroid function, which is OK if your dog has an over-active thyroid, or Graves' disease, yet I'd look into how it is processed. I'm sure this action, if also true in dogs, like in humans can vary from individual to individual & it seems certain breeds are more susceptible to hypothyroidism than others. I've been told that some large breeds can benefit from soy, as they can be prone to hyperthyroidism. Stress also plays a factor in this in humans & I imagine dogs as well, so if you are looking for the the "best food" for your dog, you might want to get an intracellular nutritional panel (blood test by your vet) done & look at food analysis of different foods to find what is best for your dog.

The soy may not be the best for all dogs, yet in others it may be essential to help your dog balance an overactive thyroid & if your dog's family has a history of hypothyroidism, it probably isn't the best. Best to consult your vet for your dog's needs, but I can say it gets gobbled up!

It's a challenge to review a dog food, because I'm not about the try it myself. However, my dog at the up quickly. He loves it over his old food.

I almost *want* to try it because of the "natural filet mignon flavor". That's right up my alley.

My dogs really like this food.  It is a great reward during training.  It's hard to find a good variety of nutritionally balanced training treats, so I was happy to find this.  The yellow and green kibbles are of a typical kibble texture and a nice size for a treat for a dog up to about 50 pounds.  The softer, squishy "meaty" looking pieces are of variable size.  Most are larger than the hard kibbles.  Some are quite small -- there will be a very small portion of the bag that ends up as topping for a meal.  Nutritionally and economically, it is not as good as the Eukanubia I use as my dogs' main diet.  So I do recommend this for use as a training treat!

The best feature about this dog food is that dogs (I have four) find it especially palatable. When it arrived, they sniffed the unopened package and would not leave its side. When it was finally offered to them (as a test for this review, of course), they were quite excited and gave it thumbs up. Note there is a package warning to mix it with old food over a number of days for an adjustment period).

What's to like: The pieces are semi-soft and come in various shapes so they are closer to dogs' natural food in the wild. The drawback is that the semi-soft pieces will not contribute to teeth cleaning as does hard. But the dogs certainly find it more appealing and it makes their mealtime more enjoyable.

(As I write this review, the dogs have gather round my computer as I placed the bag on the desk for referral purposes. Hope I can get through writing this piece without too much commmotion and distraction!)

Some of the ingredients are nice: especially the vegetables (potato and green beans); there are a variety of vitamin supplements and the food definitely has a grilled sirloin steak odor. The beef is real along with grilled sirloin steak flavor.

What is not particularly appealing is the poultry by-product meal (there is some nasty stuff in poulty by-products; four food dyes (they are labelled "colors") make the food look pretty but I would prefer the by-products and food dyes were eliminated. They seem to only serve a commercial purpose.

Because of the semi-softness of the food, it can be served to all sizes of dogs (mine range from a chow chow to a bichon-poo). I would say if there is any problem with dogs not finding food offerings very appetizing, try this food. In that department it's a winner.

Clearly this new Purina line of pet food cleverly capitalizes on recent human food trends such as chef-made dinners. The stylized food-porn photography on the packaging all target the pet owner that wants to feed the pet version of their own heat-and-eat chef-prepared meals.

The advert:
Purina's Chef Michael's TV adverts suggest that "Chef Michael" is celebrity chef Michael Chiarello. However, non of the shots actually show the face of the man in the commercial although he is of similar height, build and complexion as chef Chiarello and is dressed in clothes of a style and color that Chiarello usually wears on his shows. After some internet research, and an email to Purina, it can be concluded that chef Chiarello has nothing to do with this food. Wow! Just wow! How tricky of Purina to make a fake chef that is almost like a real celebrity chef and market their product with it.

The Food
Pros:
+ My dog was immediately attracted to the bag when it was delivered.
+ My dog was really into this kibble and I managed to use it as treats for training.
+ It looks really nice to humans, with coloured bits making it look like it was some sort of dried pet gourmet-stew.
+ The first ingredient on the list is beef.

Cons:
- Questionable ingredient quality.
- The second ingredient on the list is soybean meal and the third and fourth are soy flour and animal fat. The soybean meal and soy flour are fillers that also increase the chemical protein measurement of the food. The fourth ingredient of animal fat from unspecified sources increases the platablity of the food to pets.
- Other questionable ingredients include corn gluten meal and ground yellow corn which is again a filler and is also not easily digested by dogs.
- Food coloring is also present in this food to make it looks appealing to us so we feel better about feeding this food to our pets.
- Mendaione (chemical vitamin K) is also added to the food; studies are currently being done on this chemical form of vitamin K and latest results suggest that it may be linked to liver toxicity, allergies and red blood cell abnormalities.

My dog (after 2 weeks on this food):
+ My picky dog is inexplicably attracted to this food.
+ I can use this kibble as training treats.
- This food makes her have gas.
- This food makes her have several large greasy poops a day.
- My dog has been gagging in the morning and has thrown up undigested food a few times over the past 2 weeks. She seems to be intolerant of this food.

Conclusion:
If this food works for your dog and your wallet, then this is s good food for your dog. My dog seems to be be intolerant of this food although she really wants to eat it. As I'm not looking at this food too highly mainly because of its lack of high quality ingredients and the semi-misleading adverts, I'm not too upset at this fact. I'll be moving her back to her old food and donating the rest of this bag to the local shelter.

I was really surprised that our dog actually seemed to like this.  Usually, he is extremely picky about his food, and he normally does not like anything not chicken.  However, he seemed to enjoy this.  I thought that was great, until I checked out the ingredients.  While beef is listed first, which is important, the two next listed are soy and soy by products.  While they do have value as proteins, the value is no where near that of real meat, and the price per ounce is higher than what I pay for a dog food with lots more real protein value.  When it comes to dog food, all protein is not created equal.  If your dog is larger or a working breed, this food really will not give him the best protein bang for your money.  Most of the other ingredients are filler and empty calories. I think the coloring is a real poor choice.  The artificial chemicals used in coloring dog food are really just added to make the human consumer feel that the food is better balanced and has more variety, the color has no positive impact on the health of the dog.  I prefer to stick with more natural and healthy ingredients.  Not to mention that with the higher price per ounce, it is less filling and the dog will want to eat even more of it to fill the need for real protein.  While it may taste good to him, I would rather give him healthier food that is a better deal money wise and health wise.  I will let him eat it, since he does seem to enjoy it, but I am thinking of it more as a treat type item, and definitely not a regular part of his diet.

Our 13 year old Golden lab wants nothing to do with this food.  He smells it, took a bite then started barking at his bowl.  He finally quit when I took the bowl away and gave him Kibbles n' bits (his favorite).  I donated the bag to a local shelter, hopefully they can use it.

One of my dogs is a picky eater. You wouldn't think this would happen, but it does.

Well, she appeared to enjoy this food quite a bit. Maybe it helps that it has a variety of textures and looks like real food (as opposed to pelleted kibble). Maybe it's the smell, which seems more like actual meat and vegetables. Hard to say.

The good news is that she cleaned her bowl (for a change) and wagged her tail the whole time she was eating. I would recommend that anyone whose dog does not require special diet (our other dog does) give this food a shot.

The nuggets do have a "real food" look to them, though it was hard to tell if they were actually dried vegetables or flavored nuggets.

A softer dry food, it had a bit more aroma than other brands.

My dogs were excited about it when added to their regular dog food for a few days.

Though, after time, I think they realized it was dog food and would hold out a bit for the little touches of people food I normally give them.

The ingredients look decent for dog food. A good choice if buying higher end supermarket dog food.

I like that this dog food has beef chunks and vegetables in it. I know some people are upset about the soy, but I don't see it as an issue with my chihuahua "Tequila". Tequila is very picky about his dog food and does not eat hard brown dog food for some reason. With this dog food being multi-colored and having beef pieces I was hoping he would eat all of it.

Tequila perked up the second I opened the bag. You could tell that he loved the smell. I gave him one of the beef chunks and he immediately devoured it. I filled his bowl with the food and he excitedly ran over to it and started eating. When I walked into the kitchen later, there were hard brown chunks of food placed everywhere throughout the room. Dang dog! He did eat everything else in the bowl. So, he likes it better than a lot of other dog foods. As far as I know, there is not a dog food on the market that he will eat all of....so it gets four paws up from him. I would buy this food for my pup again.

I really tried to get my dog to eat some of the food from the bag that I was sent to review. I offered it to her several times. I even resorted to trying to wrap it in bits of ham the way that we administer pills to her. She is very picky and sometimes once you can get her to at least taste something she comes around and decide she likes it.

In this case, it didn't work out. She ate the ham and spat out the dog food. After repeating this on several different occasions I took the hint and quit trying to get her to eat the food. For whatever reason, she's just not going for this one. It's not the healthiest of dog foods, anyway, so I'm not planning to give it another shot or try another flavor any time soon.

The Chef Michael's dog food by Purina is great. Usually my dog "Champ" takes a few minutes to decide if he likes a new food or not, but he dove right in and ate this food so quickly it was almost comical. I didn't have to mix this food with this because it was already very appetizing to him. There has been no problems so far with his digestive system and his coat is still shiny so I think that its doing him good and I'll use this as more of a treat than as a meal so that when he behaves, I'll reward him with this. Good job Purina my Champ loves this dog food!!
This dry dog food smells as good as any you might buy your canine.  Our 20 pound mixed breed likes it as well as anything she has tried.  No complaints.

Sometimes, as people, we want to have special meals with food we love. Perhaps it is a place that has a special steak, or perhaps our wife or our mother makes a special family dish that we savor.

For those of us that love our pets, we sometimes want to offer our pets the same kind of treat. If this is you, Chef Michael has just the right food for your doggy's fancy. Made with good meat, what the company describes of "garnishes" of potatoes and green beans, and "prepared with care", this dog food attempts to spoil your puppy with dog food that promises healthy, yummy goodness.

Our dog enjoys this food. We can't afford to serve it to him everyday, but we will pull it out once in a while.

There are three dogs in our house: I-Don't-Eat-Dry-Food, I'll-Eat-Any-Kind-of-Food, and I'll-Eat-AnyTHING. We fed all three Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food at the same time but separately so we would know who ate what. Rocky (the dog that eats everyTHING)attacked his bowl with gusto and was begging for more. Mr. Peabody (the dog that eats anything edible) wolfed down his portion. The big surprise was that Charity, who will NOT eat anything but two flavors of Mighty Dog, went after this food like either a) she hadn't eaten in six months, or b)it's her most favorite food in the world. She gets fed twice a day, so it couldn't have been "a."

Rocky's begging for more was also a surprise. Although he'll eat anything (eyeglasses, lightbulbs, birdhouses, ant traps, flea collars, etc.) he's never before begged for more as soon as he's finished (although he will check the other dogs' dishes just in case they missed a morsel).

Please note: my five-star rating does not reflect how I would rate this product, which I did not sample, but on the dogs' enthusiastic response.

If it was only up to our dogs, they would eat this all the time. They have always come when it is time to eat, but with this one, they seem to come faster. We usually feed beneful, but even the picky one comes running for this brand. I can't really objective judge what is appealing to dogs -- they have different sense perception, but they seem to prefer this, and we are not usually too picky about what we get them, either.

We were house sitting for our neighbors the past couple of weeks and found this item that we thought might come in handy especially with their 2 pups... or 1 dog and 1 pup (don't know the age limit for canines!)

Anyway, Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin literally drove them wild. Their owners feed them Purina Dog Chow but once we opened the bag and pour a bowl full for each they dove right in and went scurrying to the bag when we put it down-- something that didn't happen with Purina.

When they came back, our neighbor, Ricardo, commented on how much the dogs seems to prefer the Chef Michael's. Now, I don't know what they're paying for the Purina or if the Chef Michael's would be a treat here and there, but one thing is certain-- The Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin made quite an impression on those dogs. They really, really love the taste of this stuff.

My dachsund just gobbles this up right away, he LOVES LOVES LOVES this grilled sirloin!  I mixed it with it Beneful, so as not to switch dogfoods on him right away and upset his small stomach, and he always picks through and nom nom noms the sirloin meaty pieces straight away before eating the rest of the dry food later, thats how much he loves Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dog Food.  Dobey is pretty picky, too.  Often his food sits around all day and he only eats as he gets hungry, but now the second it hits the bowl, he swoops in for the kills and just makes light of CM dog food, then takes his time as usual with the rest of his food, lol.  Plus this is much healthier than his other dog foods we've been through (Meijer Dog Brand and Purina Beneful), so even though it is more expensive, it seems the cost is definitly worth it.  My dog insists I continue with this brand, lol.  He absolutly salivates now and stands by his bowl when it's empty, which he has NEVER done before.  He doesn't beg for people food nearly as much (still for meat, yes, but not caring as much for anything else), and when I say my dog begs, he has very good manners which involve just sitting and watching me eat lol.  He couldn't care less unless it's meat.  This new dried food just OWNS everything else he's ever had.  Highly recommended, the price might be higher but it's also healthier for your dog baby and he will just love and appreciate you and the food so much more!  I've never seen my little guy so active as he's been since eating this lately, I can't get him to come in from outside, and he's such an indoor dog, so that's a good thing, too!  5 stars all the way for me!  Just wish it was a little cheaper.

Chef Michael's Sirloin Steak dog food is candy for dogs. They, mine included, seem to snarf it up like kids love junk food. The problem is that it IS junk food. It's filled with ingredients that should be avoided but are likely to be highly palatable to dogs and may also be appealing to their owners. Doesn't Grilled Sirloin Steak sound yummy?

Let's start with the easy part, price. I feed my dog dry Eukanuba. To compare, Chef Michel's costs 14 cents an ounce vs. 9.4 cents an ounce for Eukanuba. It is even more expensive considering that it contains 2% more moisture than Eukanuba.

Now, what's the problem with the ingredients in Chef Michael's? Here's the list of what's in it:

Beef, soybean meal, soy flour, animal fat preserved with mixed-tocopherols (form of Vitamin E), brewers rice, soy protein concentrate, corn gluten meal, ground yellow corn, glycerin, poultry by-product meal, ground wheat, animal digest, pearled barley, calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate, salt, grilled sirloin steak flavor, dried green beans, dried potatoes, sulfur, Vitamin E supplement, choline chloride, zinc sulfate, ferrous sulfate, added color (Red 40, Blue 2, Yellow 5, Yellow 6), niacin, wheat flour, potassium chloride, L-Lysine monohydrochloride, manganese sulfate, Vitamin A supplement, calcium pantothenate, thiamine mononitrate, copper sulfate, riboflavin supplement, Vitamin B-12 supplement, pyridoxine hydrochloride, garlic oil, Vitamin D-3 supplement, folic acid, calcium iodate, menadione sodium bisulfite complex (source of Vitamin K activity), biotin, sodium selenite.
Here are the questionable ingredients, in order of volume in contents:

Soybean Meal and Soy Flour: the second and third largest ingredients in Chef Michael's. After removing most of the oil from soybeans by a solvent or mechanical extraction process, grinding the remaining flakes gives you "soybean meal." "Soy flour" is another byproduct of soybean processing. These are cheap sources of protein filler used to boost the protein content of dog foods. This type of protein does not provide the dog with as much usable protein as does fish, chicken, lamb, beef or other meats. All proteins are not equal in value to the dog.

Animal Fat: the fourth largest ingredient, according to the Association of American Feed Control Officials (AAFCO), animal fat in dog food is obtained from the tissues of mammals and/or poultry in the commercial processes of rendering or extracting.
