Beef might be listed as the first ingredient but that hardly makes it the main ingredient. After reading the ingredients list this "food" seems to be mostly made up of various forms of soy. I am not a fan of soy & with all the GMO crap being pushed on us, I like it even less.

Upon presenting this artificially flavored & dyed product to my fur babies, they started to eat up. But then one by one they stopped & looked at me as if to say, "What is this crap? We don't want this. Where's the stuff you normally give us?" I left the food for them. Several hours later, the food was still in the bowl & a disgusting explosion of black runny vomit was all over everything. Jerk that I am, I continued to try to get them to eat it. After all, I have a review to do - that's how I ended up with the food in the first place. After several days I gave up. One of my babies simply stopped eating. That was the final straw. I am not torturing my pets any longer. They are back on their usual grub. No more black vomit. Everyone is once again eating until the bowls are empty & my furbabies are back to their joyful behavior.

This dog food is amazing it even smells good. Since the pieces are good size I decided to use these as rewards when our dog Sadie successfully completes a trick. Its a very effective reward and she really seems to enjoy the taste,using the product in this way is also cost effective since its not exactly cheep. I would recommend this product to dog owners, especially for training purposes!

Not sure what other criteria exists to judge dry dog food -- the shapes look like pieces of meat?

Seriously, my two dogs ate this willingly and even returned for seconds.

I may want to live on caramel and ice cream, butterfingers and apple pie - but after a few months of this diet, I'd be an overweight diabetic. This dog food, even though the name sounds (lets use the thesaurus here) resplendent, delightful, and even pulchritudinous (!) - is canine candy. I mean, come on - "Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin"? Sounds like something I'd want to eat. But read further, and it's "sirloin flavored" and is full of corn and other fillers. Sure, the way my dog devoured this looked like I had not fed him in days - he was ready to lick the chrome off the bowl. "Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin" is a name dreamed up by the marketing department.

Unfortunately, the food is flavor and filler, low quality protein, and high in carbs/calories. If your dog is a lay-about, couch potato, indoor pooch - this stuff is better as a mix-in for finicky eaters, or as an occasional treat. A dog will have to be pretty active to burn off the calories if this was his/her staple.

A week later? The dog won't touch it. Just nuzzles the stuff and gives it a tentative lick. Guess he wizened up!

Unfortunately he can't write the review!
Whenever you switch dog food on a dog they will be all excited the first time. Discovering something new in their bowl , scarfing up how ever much you give them; and then the newness goes away. A few servings and they seem tired of the taste.
Not so with this Chef Michael's product. Until the bag was empty , our dog looked forward to his morning feeding with great anticipation.
Usually the dog is in our bedroom waiting for us to get up...three of the last four days he has been sitting by his bowl.Think he likes it

My dog loved this food. He scarfed it down and wanted more. However, when I looked at the ingredients, I was disappointed. Lots of soybean meal and soy flour, and corn meal. Is it really so hard to make dog food that's not full of this stuff? When I buy Purina, I'm expecting something that is actually good for my dog as well as delicious. A definite let-down.

Opening the bag I noticed there's no zip to reseal. It would be helpful if there was even a zip closure. I had to put the bag up high because I was worried about my dog food loving cat getting in it - she was all over it. It smells like people food to me, it's got a smell that is a lot like steak.

My dog eagerly ate it, even though he really shouldn't have been all that hungry. His first taste of this was after he'd already ate his regular food. He seemed to really enjoy it and he ate it all. He can be picky about food and is one to turn his nose up at a lot of the healthier dog foods. He's also the type that will leave kibble in the bowl of a certain type in a combo if he doesn't like just that type - but he ate all of this. There wasn't a chunk left in his bowl.

The ingredient list is subpar though so I can't give it 5 starts- it has corn and soy both, and it is probably filled with GMOs. The rest looks like it is mostly animal byproducts and flavor enhancers. For the price I'd expect it to be a bit better. My dog has not had any gas issues or allergic reactions though - he is allergic to a fleas and who knows what else but this has not bothered him.

I was surprised watching out two Huskies eating Chef Michael's creation and then asking for more because they would not normally eat bagged, dry dog food unless hungry. This may be a first because, as it's probably the case with most dogs, they would rather eat human food then dog food and if human food wasn't available they'd first go for some fresh 'rabbit' or 'field mouse' if they could catch any.

I haven't tasted the food myself but our dogs seem to find it delicious. As for its nutritious qualities, the number one listed ingredient is 'beef' so it appears to be so. There is some text on the bag claiming that there are vitamins and minerals that would give the dog a shiny coat but that's probably speculation. I don't know of anything that I could eat and make my hair turn shiny so I can't see how such a miracle food ingredient could exist for dogs. If you want your dogs to have a shiny coat, there's shampoo.

The food appears to smell good too and it comes in a variety of bits, some soft, some crunchy. The bits come in different colors but that's probably something that we humans are more likely to notice or appreciate because dogs' vision is believed to be either black and white or something close to an old 50's color TV.

Since this is the first 'from the bag' food other than Milk Bone that our dogs actually love, it gets a well-deserved five star rating.

This dog food has beef as the #1 product ingredient as well as 23 essential vitamins and minerals.  Yet that isn't good enough for a lot of people out there.  Yes it has soy and corn in it.  Oh well.  Dogs will eat it up.  Who cares from what part this by-product comes from?  Dogs are scavengers folks, just check Wikipedia.  Some use this product as a dog treat -- great idea.  I suppose if you have a show dog this dog food will not be good enough for you, but what did you expect for this price?  The only think that really bothers me about this product is the food coloring added.  Is that for the dog owner or the dog?  I just can't see the dog really caring about the color of the food.  The dog bag is a thicker plastic sealed extremely well so this food is going to be air tight.  I'm not a big fan that I have to use scissors to open it however.

This Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food loved by the retriever puppy we tested it on, but I do have concerns with the content. This puppy will eat just about anything put in front of her, intended or not, but she absolutely devoured this stuff.

The issue is that it has a lot of soy, corn, and rice, and unidentified animal fat high on the ingredient list. It does have beef listed as the first ingredient, which is probably why Sissy loves it so much. I am not sure that it isn't "good enough", but this will not be our dog food of choice and it will be given as a treat on occasion.

Recommended, with the caveats above.

CFH

I'm going to have to defer to my 6-year old Wheaten Terrier regarding this Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin kibble and he gives it five big sniffs.

My dog, like many others, is highly allergic so I'm careful to make certain that the first ingredient listed is not wheat and/or corn. And, most importantly, with all the dog food scares from food made in China and distributed by US companies, I make certain that it is both manufactured AND distributed in the USA. This product met my requirements and my dog's appetite and my reward was a slobbering kiss.

Chef Michael might be a fictional character in the same vein as Aunt Jemima and the Keebler Elves, but that doesn't excuse him from putting some truly nasty ingredients into his Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food. So many other reviewers have pointed out the list of dubious ingredients that it doesn't pay to duplicate them again, but I urge you to take a long, hard look at that list before you commit to purchasing this item.

Nutrition aside, this is a very tasty food item based on my dogs' response to finding it in their bowl. Frankly, they went bonkers over Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food. I'm probably not going to make this part of their regular diet, but I will continue using it as a treat.

I have a beagle who is a pretty picky eater (weird for a Beagle, but she's kind of a diva).  So I thought she might turn her nose up at this food, but I was totally wrong! She LOVES it-we did mix it with her normal Pedigree food so that she didn't get a sick stomach from an immediate switch, and I would recommend doing that if you're switching b/c this food is much more rich and fresh than normal dry dog foods.  The ingredient list includes A LOT of added vitamins (D-3, B-12, E, K) which is better than the Pedigree I normally feed her. It is dry, which is great b/c it keeps for a long time and requires no prep other than just tossing it in the bowl! It is considered a premium dog food, so that does make it more expensive, but it's a great treat that is good for my dog and she loves it too!

I've never seen my dogs go as crazy over a dog food as when I gave this to them.  They absolutely love it.  The food looks just like it does on the bag, with pieces that are supposed to be beef that look like shredded beef and then little round balls that are supposed to be potatoes and green beans.  The potatoes and green beans are a little under 1/2 inch, but the beef pieces are closer to 3/4 to 1 inch, so this food might be best for a bigger dog.  The smell of the food is not as strong as some other dog foods we've purchased, but it definitely must have a good flavor.  It's made by Purina, which has been around forever, so I think it's a product we can feel safe using.

While other dogs may perceive this dog food as delish, my Yorkie says no. Why? I cannot know with certainty, but I suspect that she resists any dog food with corn as an ingredient. Perhaps she smelled something she does not like, but she walked away, letting me know that this was not a treat. It remains in her bowl, hours after offering it to her.

It's back to the super expensive stuff. . . and the cooked chicken. Spoiled dog? Sure, but she's a healthy dog!

If this is a snack it looks like it. The pieces remind me of cheese puffs. Their texture is puffy and it was hard for my dog to chew and swallow. The smell was appetizing even to us humans but my dog was actually scared of it after several attempts to swallow it. It has no weight and only puffed up space so it obviously has no nutritional value.
I'll keep this short as others have given long descriptions of the product.  Chef Michael's is pricey but I have a very pickey eater & she likes it.
It's true.  I've never seen him want food that wasn't in my kids happy meals more than this.  He even whined for more after his bowl was empty.  This stuff is great for at least one dog!

I have two small dogs who are very picky eaters and they like this dry dog food. They don't like many dry dog foods, but they will eat this one, especially when it's mixed with some canned dog food. They like the beef flavors of the Chef Michael's canned food, so I'm assuming this dry food must have some of the same flavors. I noticed the larger pieces of food, which appear to be those that are the beef-flavored bites, get eaten first. They do eventually finish all of the food, which with my picky eaters is something to celebrate.

I just recently moved back in with my parents. My little one is still a puppy and on puppy food, I tested it out on my parents dogs which are both adults. Since it seemed like a nice healthy choice, since my parents usually give their two chihuahuas dry food topped with a package of moist food on top. They grazed at this and didn't really finish it till their favorite part of the meal (the package of moist food) was added to the top. It is a healthy food, and just because my parents dog was not totally find it their favorite, doesn't mean all dogs will not like it. It is just not something that I will be buying on a regular basis.

My dog is spoiled. She was a rescue, but I think she forgets this. When I buy her food with crunchy dog food and soft pieces mixed up, she typically only eats the the soft pieces. And when there are both red and yellow soft dog pieces, she picks out the yellow pieces first. So, due to my dog's finicky eating habits, I did not have much hope that this dog food would impress her. Still, I try to expose her to different dog foods in hopes she will like one. We've tried quite a few varieties and I always end up giving unfinished bags to my neighbors to give to their pets.  This bag, however, will finally be finished.  My dogs loves the little steak pieces.  As a senior dog, the ability for her to easily eat the food is important and it was my perception that she was able to eat this food easily -- she ate both the moist pieces and the kibble.

I am not sure if the hype about this "gourmet" dog food is for the dogs or the owners (and I expect its the latter), but Purina has come up with a great product that the dogs really enjoy, without sacrificing any of the nutrition necessary for maintaining good canine health. Both my beloved pets and myself can recommend this food.

The 4-legged critics on my taste panel are 3 hardened street dogs who usually eat anything. Yet, they will turn up their noses at something if they don't like it. They liked this. These are rescue dogs and need fattening up. Fillers in a gourmet dog food will do nicely.
My dog approved this in no time and he is super picky about his food.it is very good quality and he loves it.

I currently use an upscale dog food, dry kibble with no grain, all meat and sweet potatoes. My dog likes it but gets sick of it unless I embellish it. So I was intrigued by Amazon's offer for me to try Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin. I decided not to replace my dog food with Chef Michael's but to use it as an enhancer and as a snack food.

Bottom-line: My dog Gretchen loves Chef Michael's, both its strong steak smell and its taste. I decided not to do a total replacement in part because Chef Michael's has soy and corn ingredients and while I'm no expert I've read that these aren't prized ingredients in a top dog food. Let me say, though, that I don't know this as fact. This is just what people in the "dog community" tell me.

However, if push came to shove and my picky dog would only eat Chef Michael's, I'd use it. For me what the dog eats is a huge factor. So if your dog doesn't have soy and/or corn allergies, you might give Chef Michael's a try.

I've got to say this is the ONLY dog food my dog has ever tried and wanted more AND I don't have to doctor it up with shredded cheddar cheese or leftovers or anything else. She just devours it! I don't know how to recommend this any higher than that.

I know it's a tad bit more expensive than some other Purina foods, but it's well worth the money. I will be purchasing Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food again, and again, and again!

Thank you Purina!!!

This is what I can tell you - my dog loves almost all of the food she eats, sneaks or straight out steals (she is a rescue dog with food issues). I cannot honestly tell you anything about this food (not having tried it myself) except that my dog loves it and snarfs it down.

After looking at it on the package and than in the bowl my wife did make the comment that this dog food looks better than a lot of the stews and casseroles we have eaten.

This part of the review is being provided by a cairn terrier -- her owner is just transcribing the notes. The terrier says: I have never been that crazy about dry dog food, especially when it's compared to that great mushy stuff that comes out of a can. But this smelled and tasted so good that I pounced on it immediately and scarfed it right up. And begged for more. It tastes like meat, so I guess it is.

From Divascribe: I was surprised at how quickly my dog took to this food -- she's never been particularly enthusiastic about dry food before. But the bag says "Real beef is the #1 ingredient." I looked at the ingredient list, and beef is listed first. There's a long, long list of other ingredients, some of which don't sound that appetizing (poultry byproduct meal), but unfortunately that's the case with most dog food. It has a nice, beefy scent that got my dog to stick her head in the bowl. My only concern is that, because I have an older dog, this might be a bit rich for her. So I plan to mix it in with her regular dry dog food for a while. No problems so far, though, and one very happy dog.

Our 4 year old mutt is loving this hearty dry dog food!  We had always been fans of the Chef Michael's wet canned food, giving it to our healthy dog since she was a year old.  But this new dry food is a great addition with thick, tasty chunks and nutritious ingredients.  The combination of veggies and meat make for a well balanced meal.  We don't add water to make it juicy since our dog loves sinking her teeth into the crunchy pieces, but for an occasional variation the added water mixes a nice soupy texture.  One thing I particularly like is that the food doesn't stink really badly like other commercially prepared pet foods.  An affordable, healthy choice for your pup.

We feed our black lab in the IQ treat ball (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003ARUKTG/). There are always a few final bits he would leave in it, but when we tried this Grilled Sirloin dry food, he would bring the ball to me to try and get even the final bits out! So it must taste pretty good. The beef pieces are a bit -odd shaped and might get stuck in those treat ball holes, but otherwise, it's fine.

The daily feeding recommendations are 1 cup per 10lb body weight which seems a bit high for beef-containing dog food. For a 50 lb dog, the 4.5 lb bag might last for ~ a week (One cup of this food is ~70-75g).

I'm slowly weaning my puppy off Puppy Chow, so I've been adding Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin dry food to his dry food. Pooper, my puppy, is a picky eater and he loves to steal cat food and he will hardly eat dry food unless I mix wet food into it. Though, he will eat this dog food without any wet food added to it. This dry food actually smells good even to me. My cats even tried to steal a piece of this dry food.

I have 4 dogs, 3 outside my husband's coonhounds and my one inside dog,Pooper, who is a lovable mutt who is 1/2 German Shepard, 1/4 Boxer and 1/4 Cocker Spaniel. I will continue to buy this dog food for my inside dog. Though, it's too pricy on my budget to feed all of my dogs.

I'd highly recommend this for any picky dog. My picky Pooper loves it.

It's dog food, so I really have to take Maggie's word for it.  She eats it, she doesn't seem to get tired of it, she even does a sort of doggie buffet where she grabs a mouthful, takes it a couple feet away from the bowl and puts down a line of the dog food then eats it.  I won't guarantee that your dog will do the buffet thing - she's a bit peculiar. Anyway, Maggie gives it 5 stars.

I always read the ingredient labels on my food to avoid product preservatives like sodium benzoate. Any food for my dog needs to meet the same standards. Costco's Kirkland branded dog foods have met my budget needs as well as provided quality nourishment. Was Chef Michael's quality enough for me to shell out twice the price? No. But then again, I'm cheap and I know it.

I personally dont have a problem with grains and soy. I grew up on the same ingredients in mom's cooking. And if it's good enough foe me, it's good enough for my dog. As long as my dogs likes the taste and receives the essential nutrients he needs, mission accomplished.

I have a dog that can be rather picky about his dog food as he much prefers to eat the human food with our dinner. Because of his tendency to develop weight problems, we really try to discourage that and keep him on dog food.

He loved this food and I had no problem getting him to accept a bowl of this happily instead of incessantly begging to share our dinner. I was quite satisfied and will definitely be purchasing this product for future use.

I generally don't give my dog food with corn or other grains because dogs are not supposed to eat them! I actually didn't realize that this food had corn until it arrived, I didn't read the list of ingredients carefully and since it wasn't the first ingredient, I was excited and quickly made the order.

My dog usually eats high quality food - either all natural foods or home made meals consisting of raw meats and vegetables. She loved this food, and ate it right away. She doesn't do that with typical dog foods unless she's really hungry so I think she enjoyed the taste. 4 stars was because it has grains in it - AND SOY!!

Our dog loved this food.  He does like most food, but he really seemed to get excited about this stuff.  It was his first adult dog food after puppy food.  He actually seemed to get a bit thin on it at times, maybe because it doesn't pack down and I was feeding him a bit less than I thought I was.  His stool seemed very healthy while on this food.  It's a good product.

Sometimes I feel sorry for our dogs having to eat the same kibble every day. We can tell that they also hate having the same stuff every day. One of the worst problems for a dog owner is getting them to eat once they become disenchanted with their fare. The problem s that once we lose them, they stay lost. But with this dry food they take an interest and dinnertime becomes competitive once agin as everyone tries to glom the kibble so as to deny the other a good meal. And we'd rather see that than watch them ignore their food altogether.

My dogs, a jack russell and chihuahua, like this dry food,  the jack russell loves eating most of the soft meaty bits first then eats the crunchy veggie bits.  The chihuahua prefers the soft meaty bits and will nibble on the crunchy veggie bits last.  I can also use both the soft and crunchy bits as training treats for the dogs.  Chef Michael's dog food also has a nice aroma, quite organic and does not smell arificial and funky like some dog food, just smells natural.  There is also a lot of natural and healthy ingredients with the food.  I would definitely buy this for my dogs again.

I'm not entirely sure if I can give an objective review for this product. Why? Well, unlike me, my dog is not a picky eater. He'll eat anything we give to him, including carrots and the occasional licking of a yogurt spoon. I think his voracious appetite was passed on to him by his predecessor, who once ate a pound of cheddar cheese my mother and I naively placed on our kitchen counter before going out to run a few errands.

So for that reason, I don't think my review is going to be all that helpful for those considering buying this product. My dog was on another brand of dog chow, but we slowly began the transition from his food to this product. When James is usually fed breakfast, lunch, or dinner, he eats it pretty fast. But once he was fully on Chef Michael's dog chow, James inhaled his meals. I have never seen my dog eat his food so fast.

So I guess it was a hit, after all!

My dogs liked the previous flavors (chicken, etc.) so I was enthused to try this new flavor.  My dogs seemed to liked this even better than the chicken.  Not sure what more to say about it since I am only able to see a visual response.  Appears to be a good, premium, slightly expensive dry dog food.

This didn't last long. The amount of food was fairly generous,but my dogs really loved it! My only complaint is my 3 three dogs liked it too much and I would be purchasing more very soon. In the future We'll mix it in with their regular food as a treat rather than a meal just so it would last. As a footnote, one of our dogs was off her feed for awhile,but this snapped her out of it.

I must confess to having two of the pickiest eaters on the planet. Granted, there are plenty of websites toting that Chef Michael's is not the best food for the pooches. I scanned the ingredients and saw that, yeah, that may be true. However, we live a very active lifestyle (to stay trim and slim) and this is a food that they devour nearly before the bowl hits the floor. Amazing. Pedigree? Not so much. Purina? Nada. Blue? Yeah, right.
With Chef Michael's, I actually garnish their bowls with fresh steamed brocoli and they adore it. Highly recommended as a food solution.

My two senior dogs are very picky eaters, they even turn down some treats! When dog food was tainted and recalled a few years ago I switched my male cockapoo and female cairn terrier to a fresh cooked diet from a pet "deli."  It is expensive and an hour from my home but they have remained on this diet because every time I tried to change back they went on hunger strikes.  I have been incoorporating Michael's dog food into their diets slowly over the past few weeks and they both have been eating every morsel.  These dogs hae been offered no less than six other brands of dog food in the past and usually they just walk away from their dishes. I finally told my family to remind me next time I complain about their food price that they will not switch and just bite the time and money bullet to keep them on the deli diet. I ordered a sample bag from the Vine review program and I am so happy to report the dog reviewers really like it. Just remember to introduce a new food gradually to ease the stress on any dog's digestive track.

Our Jack Russell is used to her controlled diet, but we sometime like to give her a handful of treats here and there. This 5 lb bag is loaded with chewy, and mixed food that she goes crazy for, and we use as a supplement for being good (watching a dog nose away the old food for this is something funny to see).

Terrific, balanced dietary food that has the feel and texture of premium food and is a superb product. Saw it on shelf at Target; got it here, really pleased with it. Chef Michael's is very, very good!

This dog food has made my dog very happy. I have been using a quality dog food before trying the Chef Michael's, and he liked it just fine, but would eat the chewy pieces first and sometimes the dry pieces would sit for a while before he would finally eat them. With Chef Michael's dog food, he not only eats the chewy pieces, but also the crunchy potato and green bean kibble. It even smells better than other dog foods and I feel pretty good about feeding him something he enjoys so much.

Beef is the first ingredient listed, which is great, and unlike some dog foods where corn is the first ingredient, corn is the 7th ingredient listed. Also listed as ingredients are 23 minerals and vitamins, including Vitamins E, B-12, and D, folic acid, niacin, calcium, manganese, potassium and lysine. However, it also contains a few strange ingredients such as "animal digest", and it has a lot of "meals" and "flours" in it. I do not know if they are optimum for dogs or are just used as fillers.

Pricewise, it compares nicely to Purina One and Beneful, which I have also fed my dog.

My two little yorkies are finicky pups. They'll eat something when it's new, but a week later turn their noses up at it. It's been a month now and they're still eating it.

When I first opened the package, they didn't exactly jump for joy. In fact, they backed away from it. I held one of the pieces out to them and they seemed very disinterested. I was thinking for a minute there they weren't going to eat it at all. And, this is a very big bag of dog food for two little dogs. However, when I put it in their dish they started eating right away. Because the pieces are rather large for small dogs, they can only eat one piece at a time. The food seems to be a bit chewy, so it takes a while to eat one piece. There's no real oder that I can smell, but because it doesn't smell like Pupa-roni they aren't fighting over it.

If they're picky eaters dogs may care about the size, shape, texture, smell, and/or taste of a food; or, if they're like my dog, they care that it stays still long enough that they can gobble it down. Owners should care about calorie content, that the food is intended for the proper age group (puppy, adult, or senior), and that the food is certified to meet the nutritional requirements set by the Association of American Feed Control Officials (AAFCO). And, unless you are independently wealthy, price.

Because my dog is not a picky eater, I can't comment on the taste of Chef Michael's. However, it is much higher in calories than a basic dog food such as Pedigree Adult Complete Nutrition Small Crunchy Bites Original Beef Dry Dog Food, 30-Pound, which means that a much smaller amount should be fed, something that she definitely objects to.

There is one notable point about Chef Michael's-
All pet foods produced in the United States must meet certain minimal nutritional requirements, which are set by AAFCO. Somewhere on its bag or can each food will have a short statement saying that is has either been *formulated* to meet AAFCO standards, or has undergone *feeding trials* and been shown to meet AAFCO standards. AAFCO has set standards for 2 life stages; growth (i.e. puppies) and reproduction, and adult. (Senior is not recognized as a separate stage.) Because feeding trials are so expensive, such foods are usually formulated to meet the needs of *all life stages*. Growth and gestation/lactation have much higher nutritional requirements than a normal adult dog has. Therefore, such a food may not be ideal, particularly if you pet has a weight problem. Foods that are *formulated* (i.e. do not undergo feeding tests), are more often designed to meet the needs of a specific life stage. Chef Michael's is the only pet food (dog or cat), that I have ever found that has undergone feeding trials AND is designed for a specific life stage.

The importance of feeding trials, formulations, and life stages is debatable, and in the end is an individual decision.

Finally, despite what some people claim, it is not possible to assess the quality of a food from the ingredient list. Ingredient descriptions, for example any listing of a meat product or by-product, are vague and there can be huge variation in the quality of a product with the same name from one food to another. In the same vein, claims that certain ingredients shouldn't be in dog food should be taken with a grain (or large jar) of salt. When chosing a food for your pet, talk to your vet, don't believe a stranger on the internet with unknown qualifications.

As for me, although my dog enjoyed Chef Michael's, both the calorie content and price are too high to make it her normal dog food.

I have two dogs, both Pomeranians. One is 16 and has no teeth, and the other is eight and an extremely picky eater. My older dog will eat just about anything, so it was no surprise to me that the minute I poured this into a bowl he beelined straight for it and tried to chow down. Only -- poor dog -- these pieces were too hard and too large for him.

The picky eater, on the other hand, gave these a whiff and timidly tried a few bites. In my household, this is a success! It's a rare story for him to even try anything new we buy for him. We leave these out all day for the dogs to eat whenever they get hungry and I will spy the picky dog going for a nibble throughout the day.

Mickey, my toy poodle..who is overweight by the way, has been eating Beneful (healthy weight) not sure why, since he is as I stated overweight. I was trying to save this bag for when I ran out of the big bag I already have. I noticed that Mickey eats all of the soft pieces from his bowl, and leaves the others there until he is starving,so I thought why not try it out.

Well he was excited by the bag itself..and it does look good enough for human consumption if you just look at the bag, so he probably thought it was real food, I don't think he caught the "Chef Michael" but maybe he did since he sometimes acts as if he can read. Anyway, he was jumping up and down and ready to eat.

I only give him half a cup, but he munched it right up. Afterwards, I caught him going in the bag..which he never does, so I had to lock it up! This am, he was so ready to eat that he came straight in from his morning business..I didn't have to call him or hunt him down!

I don't know if it's actually good for him..I don't read labels..sorry but from some of the other reviews..it ain't good for him! If Mickey were writing the review I think he would give it 10 stars..maybe his old food is boring. If you are concerned about the ingredients, you may want to pick another kind. Mickey is 8yrs old..so I treat him like a senior citizen and let him eat almost whatever he wants. :)
The dogs absolutely love it! It's not boring like other brands and the ingredient list gives me the impression that someone has put a lot of thoughts into the production of this item.

First of all, I really like this dog food because the first ingredient is real beef, not grains or gluten.
Second, the meat has a really interesting texture - like a cross between beef jerky and a puffed snack. The vegetables are like regular dog kibble.
Third, my dog really loves this! We have a 13 pound dog and the pieces aren't too big for him. Usually he gets tired of his dog food after a while, but so far he still loves this food! Unfortunately he keeps begging for it when it isn't time to eat, haha...
I would definitely order this food for our dog again.

I used to tell of the tales when I worked as a stock boy at a local grocery, and wondered about all the old people in the dog food aisle, looking at the better canned brands. I remarked to one of the other stockers that old people must really love their dogs they are always buying the best stuff. I would never get anything beyond dry for my sisters cat. They basically told me I didn't understand the situation, these people were on social security with no savings and could barely afford utilities. They bought good dogfood cause they got it for themselves!

Well that said, the gal Karine, that takes care of my poodle while I work in Chicago said that if she got to that bad in retirement, she would condsider eating this dog food, Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin. Because my poodle Sandy would pick it off the top of the bowl, she mixed it with the other dry food. Sandy stays in a large pen during part of the day, his food and water are there. When Karine returned to walk Sandy, she noticed that the food was spread over one of the pads in the pen, and all the Chef Michael's stuff was picked out!

The very top or the most prominant ingredient in this food was beef, and the stuff looks like it, and apparently the dog has judged it to be better than the average fare. Smart dog, it looks pretty healthy too from the rest of the ingredients. I will likely buy this one, as a good suppliment to mix with the EVO I usually buy.

My dogs really seemed to like Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin dog food, judging by the way they gobbled it up. The company that makes this has a come a looooong way in choosing the best ingredients with nutrition in mind. Real meat is the first thing on the list of what it's made from, and they use a vitamin E preservative instead of BHA or BHT. (I won't feed my dogs anything made with that crap)

I was happily surprised with the high quality of this food, and I bought another bag for the pooches the other day.

My picky eater actually likes this dry food and he doesn't like much.  He's always been a fan of Chef Michael's wet food but there aren't many bags of dry food that he will eat without my having to jazz them up with gravy, table scraps, etc.  The Chef Michael's dry food apparently is the one rare exception.

Didn't like the taste of it much myself, but the same can't be said for my dog.  He must really like it considering he usually takes his sweet time getting to his dog dish.  He seems a bit more anxious to get to this, so it must be good.

I have a large mutt who is a fairly fussy eater. When I was offered the opportunity to review this dog food, I thought Buck was in for a treat from some fancy dog food - a nice change from the usual kibble. And, my first impression, when I opened the bag of dog food, was "Oh, this looks good."

But, it was all downhill from there. First I looked on the bag to see how much I was supposed to feed my dog. One cup per 10 pounds. One cup per 10 pounds! That's 8 cups/day for my large dog. There's a lot of filler in this dog food. I feed 3 1/2 cups/day of my regular dog food.

So, I thought maybe the Chef Michael's would be better used as a replacement for just a small portion of the regular food to give Buck a treat. Based on the appearance, I was sure it must taste good. Much to my surprise, my dog did not really care for this dog food. He didn't hate it and did eventually eat what I put out, but was not at all enthusiastic about it.

My elderly dog (15 year old beagle) can't see much any more, or hear much, but she still really enjoys her food. Zoe usually turns her nose up at anything other than her regular food, but not this time. She dived in and did't stop until it was gone. Not wanting to change completely, we mixed it with her life long food - Science Diet. She picked out the Chef Michael's pieces and at them first. It's softer than regular dry and I think she liked that, and it smell good, even to me.
There is a variety of shapes and we saved the bigger chunks to give her as a treat. That's how much she loves this food. My picky eater picked Chef Michaels! And at 15, she get anything she wants.

If my dog could write this review, I'm pretty sure she would say "This is the best dog food EVER!". Zoe is 7 years old and a very healthy eater. She eats her food as soon as we put it down. We normally feed her a dry, grain-free food because I think it's the most nutritious for her and the best for her teeth. We alternate between a turkey and sweet potato food and a salmon and sweet potato food. She eats it just fine. But, let's face it, our dogs would rather be eating what we're eating. I think she thinks Chef Michael's is people food. I've never seen her more enthusiastic about breakfast and dinner times.

But, as her father, it's my job to make sure she's getting the best food for her. I'm not 100% convinced Chef Michael's is it. There is no consensus on whether grain is good for your dog. But, we've decided to go with foods that don't include grains. Chef Michael's, #1 ingredient is beef. So, that' good. But, that's followed by soy and then a whole host of grains. So, if I had to guess, I would say this food is largely, if not mostly grains (if you add all the grains up together). Ingredients are listed by the which is the most first in descending order. But, just because an ingredient is first doesn't mean the others don't add up to more than it. The longer the list of ingredients, the more likely that is. Just like with people food, I think generally, the shorter the list of ingredients the better (except for when you get into the added nutrients at the end- vitamins, minerals, etc.). As for potatoes and green beans, those follow sirloin flavoring on the list of ingredients. Since sirloin flavoring is added, that probably indicates the beef isn't sirloin steak (I know you're shocked). So, don't be lulled into thinking you're feeding your dog a sirloin, green bean and potato dinner here. You're feeding her beef, grains and some bits probably colored and flavored to looks like green beans and potatoes. Another thing about the food that your dog will probably love is it's semi-moist and semi-soft. I think dogs prefer moist foods over dry. We feed dry because I think it's better for her teeth. Also, when you buy moist food, you are paying for water as opposed to nutritional ingredients. This food only has about 15% less calories per cup than the food I feed my dog. But, the feeding instruction on the bag say to feed one cup for every 10 pounds of your dog's weight. I don't know how much you feed your dog. But, we feed our 70 pound lab-mixed breed a cup in the morning and a cup in the evening. I cannot imagine feeding her 7 cups of any food per day.

Personally, I wouldn't serve this to my dog every day for the reasons stated above. But, I'm sure she'd love it if I did. I think it's a great treat for her and maybe a little break from the boring dry food we feed her. I don't think it would be a horrible choice for a long term food though. For those reasons, I give it four stars.

We normally feed our dog beneful, it's what she was fed in the rescue center, she does like it & always looks for more. When I saw Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin, I thought, yeah right, no way there's meat in there.

It is more expensive than beneful, but my dog really, really likes this brand. I'm sure there are a gizzilion bad things in this, but if you add a bit of water, the meat pieces do get soft & has the consistency of wet dog food. It's not all meat, the filler pieces of green & yellow kibble are the same as beneful (vegatables & soy & fillers, etc - green beans - really???).

This is a nice treat for our dog, she likes it almost as much as canned food, but this has the convenience of dry dog food.

Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food claims to be more than your boring kibble and they are right.  The pieces come in a couple different shapes and sizes.  It has round crunchy kibble and more jagged shaped tender pieces (although the "tender pieces" started to get harder the less there is even though the "Best if Used By" is about a year and a half after I got the bag).  Of course the look and feel of the food does not mean anything if the dogs refuse to eat it, but both of my dogs dug right in right when I put their bowls in front of them.  The only problem I ran into was that one of my dogs is an elderly Chihuahua with many of his teeth taken out due to rotting who was slower to eat the bigger "tender pieces" and since it took him much longer to finish his dinner than my other dog, they sometimes would get in a growling match because my other dog would sit and try to finish off the bowl for the Chihuahua.

I foster for local dog rescues so my pack is a little larger than the average home. Some of the dogs are picky eaters so I struggle to find a dog food that will please them all. Sadly Chef Michaels was not one that will make them all happy. About 75% of my dogs ate the food just fine but some of them wanted nothing to do with it. I guess it just depends on whether your dog will love it or not.

Here is one of those products that is marketed more to the consumer (human). It is almost as appetizing to the human food critic's eyes with both eye appeal and color of the food. With that being said... My dog liked this Purina dog food, by Chef Michael's, just fine. He finished the bag off completely, without discrimination. Honestly, he does this with just about any quality of food. I guess I got lucky that way. It is unfortunate that my dog does know what it's like to be hungry, thus he is less likely to be finicky.

I do believe in healthy foods for my pet and not so much those filler ingredients. However, these foods can be supplemented in his diet by adding veggies and whole meats to any brand of dog food that is not fortified or primaried with such, and Purina is no exception.

In addition to their bagged dog food, I like to give my dog a hearty beef rib once a week. This only costs an additional $10.00 for a rack of 8-12 hearty ribs. Not to shabby for a 2-3 month supply.

As a consumer, I rely mostly on the marketing of what is in the packages ingredients list and trusting that Purina is using the ingredients of the highest quality in this and all of their products. And when they list beef as the first ingredient, that it is the primary ingredient and not made with the least amount. And down the near future, I do not hear about a recall on this pet food because it was tainted with... who knows what.

As far as the dog food goes, it was liked by my pet and he did seem to enjoy it, that's what matters most. I truly hope it is benefical for him and that my pet gets a good nutritious meal out of it.

I was hoping my dog wouldn't like this dog food. I already have a nice, boring brand that I buy for him. It's healthy and although he doesn't jump up and down for it, he eats it. He reacts a bit differently with this one. He goes nuts for it!  It is dry and at times he has coughed a little after eating it too fast, but he has learned not to do that. I'll be buying it. I'm not sure yet if it will be a new staple in his diet or for special occasions.

My two Labradors took to this food right out of the bag and finished off the sample bag (from the vine program) in short order. Being that the main ingredient is meats, it is exactly what you should be feeding your dogs.

I highly recommend this food.

I have 4 dogs & we're very picky on their food.
Because of that - we give them IAMS
But I know they get tired of the same food so we always get a "filler" food to add in the bottom of their IAMS - gives them something to look forward to.
They are picky eaters... usually what they like the best if Kibble N Bits ... anything else, they'll leave some at the bottom. But tried this because I've heard Chef Michael's is healthier then other brands...
the dogs love it... eat every bit of it...
I dont give a lot where I have to worry about digestion changes - which is nice - but will keep an eye out to get more of this to add to their bowls.

We recently changed our dog's normal food because she has gotten picky and no longer wants to eat the premium brand we've bought for several years. We've tried several types thus far and she likes them all (who says dogs don't need variety in their food?). Since the Chef Michael's was offered as part of the Amazon Vine program, I decided to give it a try. The first day of trying Chef Michael's, as soon as I mixed it with her current food, she gobbled the whole bowl. That's different for her. She usually leaves some of her food so she can eat throughout the day. As time has gone by, I've noticed she will dig through the bowl of mixed food and pick out the Chef Michael's pieces, eat them first and then nibble on the other brand in the bowl. If she leaves any food in the bowl to come back and eat later in the day, it's always the other food, not Chef Michael's.

Yes, the Chef Michael's food is expensive but it's not out of line with other the other premium dog foods we've been buying at the pet store. As a matter of fact, it's considerably lower priced than some of them. So price is not really a big factor in buying this dog food if you've been buying premium brands all along.

The ingredients are consideration, however. Some of the ingredients in the Chef Michael's is not exactly on the politically correct list for healthy eating. For that reason, we will probably continue to follow our current procedure of mixing a little of the Chef Michael's with a larger quantity of another type of premium and better nutritionally balanced food. Our pooch loves it and adding a little pizzazz to her meals brightens up her day. That's worth a lot.

If this review was based on nutritional value alone, I would probably give it 3 stars. It's not really bad as far as nutrition is concerned but it's not as good as other foods within the same price range. But I bow to the family dog whose opinion is paramount.

This Chef Michael's grilled sirloin flavor went over well with the dogs, while both are older the lapdog has a hard time with some dry foods, he was able to chew through this. I like to change dog foods often to avoid a build up of any one ingredient or vitamin, some dog foods give the dogs loose stool, but we had no problems with this. First ingredient is beef, soy, animal fat, brewers rice, corn coming far down the list which is something I prefer, we will buy this dog food again.

Obviously I am not going to taste this stuff.  But the dog loves it.  In fact he likes it so much that he no longer wants eat his regular food, so I am now using the as treat food.  Really can't find anything bad to say about the food.  Our dog goes the town on it with the same zeal he normally holds for wet food.

I have two large dogs and a relative budget.  So this maybe terrible of me, but I don't mind a little filler.  And my dogs are healthy and active (even the senior) and they've been fed on easily accessible and relatively affordable brands all of their lives.  Though there are some questionable ingredients in Chef Michaels, and some known fillers, the number one ingredient is beef and this flavor also includes filet mignon flavors, green beans and potatoes. I should say it's a pretty small bag for the cost, so over the long term this may cost twice as much. However, they really did seem to enjoy it.  I would purchase this again.

Our 2 dogs tried Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Steak Flavor dog food, made with real beef. One is a Basset and one a smaller Terrier. Both ate without any hesitation. The food is colorful (for the human appeal) with crunchy kibbles as well as tender pieces. I prefer to feed our dogs crunchy kibbles if they are able to eat it, because I think it keeps their teeth cleaner. There seemed to be more large tender pieces than crunchy, but the dogs loved it all. The food size was fine for both the large dog and the small dog. The large dog transitioned from her regular food to Chef's with no trouble. The smaller dog had some digestive issues for a few days (very soft stools) until that cleared up and she was fine. The bag claims "23 essential vitamins & minerals" and a "well rounded meal for adult dogs".

One nice packaging plus was the bag shows the actual size pieces of food, something helpful to me with 2 different sized dogs. Overall, I could say the food was a hit at this dog house.

My dog really loved the taste of this food.  It has meat chunks mixed with kibble, although the meat looks a bit like pink play-dough.  I've found it to be a perfect treat to stuff inside her Kong to keep her busy, since it is tasty and attractive but not messy and won't stick to the inside of the kong. I wouldn't use it personally as her main food however since corn and soy and corn and soy products are at the top of the ingredient list.  (Although meat is the first ingredient which is a plus, since many commercial pet food has corn or soy as the number one ingredient).  However, since pretty much all US grown soy and corn is GMO, I try to limit that in pet foods that I use as the main food for my pets.  Dogs are omnivores, however they are not intended to eat a majority of their food as grain so always avoid foods with corn as number one ingredient.  This seems like a higher end commercial brand, but nutritionally there are much, much better options (Innova, Solid Gold).  As a treat, however, I think this is a great product and probably less fat and junk than most dog "treat" products.

My dogs are always begging for table scrapes.  As we all know that own dogs it is not good to give in to them.  We have many dogs and as I said they are not crazy about any dog food that we offer them. I keep telling them they are not people, but they just don't seem to get the hint. I brought the bag of Chef Michael's food into the kitchen and opened it up, to my surprise I had 5 dogs around me within minutes. How could they smell food that fast? Amazing.  I put a cup full in each of their dishes and set it down for them. Before I had the last dish down the dogs had finished the first ones. What?  My dogs hate dry dog food, what were they doing eating this?  I decided to do a little experiment and put down some of their regular food and some of Chef Michael's, side by side.  They all tried to get chef Michaels and totally ignored their regular dog food. I put it up and decided I'd try again the next day knowing sometimes they gobble up something the first time just because its new.  The next day I did the same thing and again they all charged for Chef Michael's food.  There you have it. My dogs loved it, and since it is dog food they have the final say.

Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin was a very nice, tasty change that our dog absolutely loved.

He has been eating grain free Taste Of The Wild for a few months. He picks at it, and eats what he needs to, I guess, but he never "gobbles it up." I never get the impression that he eats it and likes it - it is more like he eats it because he knows it's his food and he has to eat. He would always be really impatient, licking his lips and sitting by my feet at the stove, when I cook dinner because he so much looked forward to his steak, pork chop or chicken breast. (Yes, I cook a fat trimmed meat serving especially for him, without seasonings, etc, and he eats dinner when we do. His food bowl is always filled as well though and he can graze as he pleases. Alot of people think this is bad, but as long as he is as healthy and muscular as he is, the vet said we are doing fine for him.)

Moving onto the new stuff...I filled his dish with the Chef Michael's and he really went right into it and cleaned the bowl. It looks and smells like it would be tasty/appealing to a dog. It certainly looks more appetizing than the other food that is all one shape and size. It definitely has a meaty (although processed/artificial) smell.

There is no doubt that he thoroughly loved every bit of it. He was excitied from the moment he sniffed at it as I poured it in his bowl. He sat there wagging his tail and licking his chops as I filled the container to his automatic feeding bowl - he knows he has to "wait" and keep his nose out of the bowl as I fill it. I could tell he was happy and excited to try something yummy and new. For the few days this bag lasted, he wasn't as anxious when he knew I was cooking dinner. This dog food must have satisfied his taste buds much better than the Taste Of The Wild.

I do think it is more of a "treat" or junk food though and not something that I would buy continuously and feed exclusively. It is fairly pricy and the nutrition content is not totally on par with what I like for him. I mean, it's not absolutely terrible nutrition-wise, but it isn't the healthiest either. It does have some fillers, but I have seen much, much worse on the market. This at least has actual meat as the first ingredient.

I plan to buy these smaller 4.5 bags occasionaly and add a handful or so into his regular food once a day or every few days, for a little extra flavor or treat. Taste Of the Wild is good for him, but it really doesn't seem as appealing as something like this Chef Michael's. We all like a little junk/fast food every now and then and I imagine our dog does as well. This 4.5lb bag lasted him about 3.5 days while he ate it exclusively. It just seems like this would be pretty expensive to feed as his regular food. If it was totally nutritious and healthy for him, I wouldn't mind the cost. Plus, I could definitely see a pet overeating it just because it (apparently) tastes so good and/or because it would provide empty calories and he would end up hungry more often/sooner between meals - just like when people eat fast/junk food.

Overall, I give it a good 4 stars. I knocked the one star off for the cost/nutrition ratio.

Boy, am I so tired of reading reviews bemoaning the ingredients in dog food these days.  All the whiners claim that such-and-such is too corm or soy heavy, or that it is not gluten free or some other such crap.  Guess what...It's DOG FOOD! For the love of all that is holy would you tools quit your whine-fest and go away!  For the record, this product did exactly what it was supposed to do.  Do you know what that is?  It fed my dogs.  Furthermore, they all seemed to enjoy it and have not shown any ill effects or digestive ailments (Not a single degree higher on the dog-fart scale, so I am happy).  Sure our dogs are our babies, but the same people who cry about dog food ingredients are the same ones who took the score out of childrens' sports and think everyone is a winner.  Total and complete imbeciles.  Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food will always be welcome in my home.  Our pets are only given a short time with us on this planet, so why not let them enjoy their little lives to the fullest.  Give them what they want.  If this dog food makes them wag their happy little tails, then have at it.  I found this to be a great product and I hope you do to.  The naysayers need to get a grip on reality or just raise children instead.  They don't deserve dogs!  Highly Recommended!

Wow, do our dogs ever love this food!  It is softer and much meatier than other dog food we've purchased.  Our older cat likes it too.  I think the fact that it's not as crunchy is easier on the older dogs teeth.  This is a real treat for them.

I received a bag of this dog food through the Amazon Vine program, and when I sprung it on my two dogs, they couldn't get enough of it. Wow, do they love this stuff. Ever since I began feeding them this food, they actually seem like happier pets.

The only drawback is that they wolf it down very fast after I dump it in the dog dishes, acting as though they've never eaten before. But it makes them happy and that's the important thing.

Ground Yellow Corn, Corn Gluten Meal, Animal Fat preserved in mixed-tocopherols and Soy: Be very careful of these ingredients.

If you spot them in any dog food, it's a giant red flag. It seems a lot of Dog Food these days just have to have them. My dog absolutely loved this brand, but at the moment, I am treating this bag as a treat, just like we give chocolate to kids. We know they aren't really good for your health, but I am hoping giving them once in a while won't hurt them too much.

Go with certified brands like Canidae and Wellness, and stay away from ones that contain those ingredients I listed above.

This food appears attractive and healthy when poured into a bowl - it looks like chunks of dried meat among veggie-rich kibbles. My dog very happily scarfed it down.

I, unfortunately, read the ingredient list. It is extremely soy and corn heavy (both almost guaranteed to be GM), and includes nasty items like poultry by-product meal and animal digest. Whatever those chunks are, they are in no way related to real meat.

As much as my dog loved this, I will not be making it part of his regular diet - it's just not real food.

I ordered this without first reading the ingredients--was suckered in by the name and the packaging when looking at amazon's vine program offerings last month.
As a compulsive label reader and nutrition researcher this was completely my bad and I own it.
That said, this is one of the more expensive "junk foods" for dogs that I have seen lately. While it may have beef as the first ingredient, when you factor in all the remaining negative ingredients there is simply no way to offset the good with the bad. Other reviews have gone into great detail on the ingredients and their negative impact on your pet's health so I'm not going to repeat that. Just chiming in!
It frustrates me when people say they can't afford to feed their families or pets good quality, nutritious food (as opposed to factory produced calories packaged in grocery stores and served in restaurants).
When you factor in the cost to your health and the fact that you are nutritionally starving yourself (or your family/pets) the cost for good food (and I mean FOOD, not calories) is actually less expensive.
Off the soapbox...

My older dog loved this dog food, maybe because it is soft and easy to chew. My "puppy" scarfed it down, but she had bad runs afterward (though to be fair, I have heard that anytime you switch up your dog's food that can happen).

I researched this dog food at Dog Food Advisor. They analyzed the ingredients in Chef Michael's, concluding that it uses soybean meal, soy protein concentrate and corn gluten meal to boost the protein content, and that it likely only has a modest amount of meat. They do not recommend it. Based on my experience, that is good advice.

Of course it does!  Unless you have one of those super rotten dogs that barks constantly, bites little kids, and begs even when you reach for the remote.  This is faaaaar to good for THAT dog.  But certainly a very nice change of pace for well-behaved pooches of all shapes and sizes.  Clearly I can't get an exact read on what my dogs liked so much about the food, though I will say upon initially opening the bag that I nearly ate a nugget(long day at work and looks and smells delicious!).  If a grown man nearly couldn't resist diving in, just think how much your dogs will like it!  Maybe that should be their slogan?

This was a big hit at the kennel that masquerades as our home.

Here's some background on the test subjects:
We have 3 dogs (basset hound, black lab, rottweiler) that vary in size from 50 to 75 pounds.
They go through a 15.5 lbs of Beneful Healthy Weight dog food every week at a cost of about $15.
The basset and rotty eat everything in sight. The black lab is a very finicky eater.

With that in mind, here's my review:

Chef Michael's food is chewier, the meat bits anyway, than the dry food that we use. The dogs love that and they scoffed it up, even finicky Ashley.

It's pieces are also smaller in size which they apparently like because they eat it much faster.

Based on our dogs eating habits, we would need about 3.5 bags of Chef Michael's awesome food per week. This would cost about $35, an increase of $20 per week to feed the hounds.

It's a great product. However, if money is a factor, I would recommend it for owners that have 1 small to medium size dog.

Also, if you're going to pay that much, the bag should be resealable. This and the cost is what made me knock it down to 4 stars.

UPDATE: 8/28 While this food is expensive, it turns out that my one dog Ashley after eating this wont eat the other food that we usually have to doctor with parm cheese and bread crumbs. We gave up and bought another bag today. Ashley ate it right up. We have decided to feed Ashley this and the other dogs can eat the Beneficial. We paid 2.00 more at the grocery store for this food so we ordered to more bags via Amazon. For a picky eater it is worth it.

My Jack Russell Terrier has always been a grazer. No chugging down food for him. We feed him twice a day, a.m. and p.m. and the food goes slowly when he's hungry throughout the day and evening. We've been giving him a dry organic kibble mixed with a wet organic canned food. He likes it well enough but I don't think he gets much pleasure from eating.

I decided to try the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food. What a surprise. My dog, Sky, went to town and ate it all at once. I was a little nervous that his digestive system would be upset but he's as good as new. No upsets. What is really nice is that he enjoys eating his food. It's there and gone quickly. He savors his food and eats it in one sitting. It's nice to see that. I will be using this dog food in the future. If Sky could talk, he would thank Vine and Purina for the opportunity of trying this dog food.

By the way, I switched all at once from one diet to the other and there were no repercussions.

I'm always a little challenged to review something my dogs eat, but in this case, my dogs have enthusiastically communicated that they enjoyed this product. So as far as taste goes, this is a winner.

But what about nutrition? Most of the leading ingredients are proteins, which puts this in a different category of quality from the more corn based dog foods (this still does have corn and rice, but they seem to be about a fifth of the content). Much of the protein is from soy instead of animals. It's also been dyed, which doesn't seem necessary to me. It looks pleasing to people, but there's not much reason to give a dog colored food. But in my opinion, a dog can be healthy eating this as long as it's part of a balanced diet.

I would add veggies and actual meat from my own dinners to my dog's diet. I tend to give them both at least a serving every day, but then they eat some kind of normal dog food for the majority of their diet. This approach has led to my dogs being healthy and living long lives.

There are more expensive and healthier dog foods, but Chef Michael's dog food is a healthier and apparently tastier alternative to the other grocery store brands.

I have to admit up front that I don't own a dog.  But my fiancée and my neighbor do. A Golden Retriever and a Datsun respectively.  Both of them are fussy about what their dogs eat, but not what I would call fanatical.  Both of them also agreed that this dog food is very far from the worse that they have tried as far as quality goes.  But at the same time for the price they are suggesting the nutritional value could be much better.  As for the dogs review, there is no question that they both loved it.  Not only did they both savor it fully, but there were no side effects noted in either dog as to gas, bloating, belly aches, etc.  My conclusion based on their reviews and remarks is that this is a medium to very good quality dog food that carries a premium price.  But also one that both dogs in the tests here seem to gobble up enthusiastically.  My suggestion would be to perhaps buy this for a delicious treat for your dog, and pick up something else a little more reasonably priced for their everyday diet... : )

Our two large dogs really like this product. They gobbled it down and wanted more. Since they are on the chunky side, we try to limit their food intake a bit. This dog food satisfied them and gave them a meal which they really appeared to enjoy.

My 8 year old dog loved Chef Michaels Grilled Sirloin food.  I loved that the very first ingredient is beef and that the bits of food look like little chunks of food and that the dog food didn't smell horrible like some dog foods.  The 4.5 lb bag lasted us about 2 weeks with a once a day feeding schedule.

My dogs LOVE this food. In fact, if I fill their bowls with it, they won't stop eating until it is gone. So I have started putting a little bit on top of their regular food, Wellness, as a little treat. They can't get enough of it! They actually make a complete mess digging through the bowl of regular food to find the Chef Michael's food, spilling their food everywhere! They think this food is better than the actual treats I give them.

It also looks good. Kibble is usually these nondescript little balls of unidentifiable substance, but Chef Michael's LOOKS like real food! My dogs are picky about their kibble, but they certainly love this stuff!!

I have two maltese dogs, a male who is 13 and a female who is 11.  The female will eat nearly anything that doesn't try to eat her first.  The male will hardly eat at all unless you beg him.  Both of them liked the grilled sirloin part pretty well.  The "potato and green bean garnish" part tended to stay in the bowl a while, though my little girl would eventually eat that, too, usually.  Dogs are not fans of veggies of any kind and so I was not surprised.  But overall, they liked it pretty well, which is saying a lot for what is mostly a dry dog food.  I have not seen this in the store where I buy my dog food.  When it does (and if it does) the price will determine for me whether I'll start buying this brand or stay with the brand I was already using.  I think my dogs liked this enough that I'd be willing to switch, but only if the price was the same or not much more.

I have to state up front that my dog is a very picky eater, so judging any kind of food with him is tricky.  The first thing I noticed is that the bag I received was not resealable.  The scissor cut line is below what looked like a zipper line, but the bag did not open until I cut below it.  The food itself is very different looking and smells very nice, as far as dog food goes.  My dog initially turned his nose up at it, but went back to eating virtually everything put in his bowl within a few hours.  That's more than he will for almost every dry dog food I've tried with him.  Most likely, I will try another bag of Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dog Food in the future.

My dog is not the most persnickety dog I've ever met; she eats raccoon poop sometimes, but then again she won't eat just anything--won't touch half the veggie food that I serve at the table. But this food, she loves. She usually eats most dog foods just until she's full and then leaves the rest for later. But this food she eats like a kid eats candy. I think she would eat the whole bag if I let her.

The food pieces are moist and tender, not as moist as canned food, but not crunchy like other dry dog food. There are little pieces that look like meat, but when you look closely you can tell it's some sort of conglomerate food, sort of like a chicken nugget idea. There's obviously food coloring in here-- the pieces are different pretty colors. How do dogs do with red 40? She seems fine after eating one dose anyway.

Okay, personal problem here... is it ethical to be eating a vegan diet myself and be serving sirloin beef to my dog? I can justify serving the dog the leftover meat stuff that probably wouldn't be used for anything else and would probably be thrown away otherwise. But to kill one mammal to feed another? Even if she is my best buddy, that bothers me. She likes it. So, whatever, I'll think this over and see if I keep buying it.

My dogs were INSANE for this food when it hit their food dish. The two of them took turns darting in for a mouthful which is amazing, since they usually eat at completely different times. I would caution to put out a limited amount at first, because my littlest dog ate and ate til she had to run outside to throw up - it was so good she just couldn't stop.

I will definitely be purchasing this food for my dogs.

This is good stuff for our paunchy pug! For a while our dog, Ruby, wasn't eating hard food, due to problems with her teeth, but now that she's able to again, Chef Michael's by Purina seems to suit our canine just fine. In fact, she eats it with gusto (like most everything else!). This blend smells like normal dog food but is more varied than the typical stuff we give Ruby. It's got the "grilled sirloin steak flavor," which she's used to, but the "potato and green bean garnishes" are something different -- and I think she likes the added taste. The kibble colors are an interesting mix of bacon-looking brown, light brown and green (which I assume is the green bean portion).

I get the feeling that Purina puts a lot of effort and sincerity into its products, and I like the fact that there are 23 crucial minerals and vitamins to enhance Ruby's health. The food is a mix of "tender pieces" and "crunchy kibbles," which again provides some diversity compared to what our dog is usually fed.

Authentic beef, protein, veggies and important nutrients -- what else could your lovable pooch want in a meal? Well, except for your table scraps, of course!

Our Chihuahua is not a picky eater by any means, she will eat just about anything that is given to her.
We normally feed her Iams dog food and occasionally she gets wet dog food (actually, we purchase the Chef Michael's wet canned dog food and she loves it), and that is a huge treat to her.
Every day when we feed her the Iams dry food, she could really care less and eats it as she pleases (but does finish her food).
We have been feeding her the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food for a little over a week now, and she is waiting by her dish to be fed, she acts as if this is a dog treat for her.
The dog food looks a little odd, but our dog loves it!
So far, yes it has been only a little over a week of her eating it daily, and no complaints. If something changes I will most definately update.
I am thinking, this may be our Chihuahuas new choice in dog food!

My girls are very picky about what they eat and we rarely try any new products anymore because we usually end up giving most of bag to another dog. This time they fooled us. They absolutely love this stuff. It is supposed to smell like sirloin steak which it must since they rush to gobble it down. They have never cared for hamburgers all that much....pampered pets like steaks instead and this must actually smell like steak. So rather than giving this bag away, we will be buying more!

What a great way to spoil your dog! I'm glad we got a chance to try these out because the dogs enjoyed them very much. Mind you, Chloe and JJ are not picky, they'd eat a worn out gym sock if I put it on a plate and said "yum". But, this product is actually good for them and they enjoy it. All kidding aside, this is a quality product that your dog will enjoy, just remember to keep your socks on, eh?

I have a Lab and a Papillon.  The Lab will eat anything and this works great.  The Papillon is picky and likes it better than any other dry food I've tried.  The food looks and smells appetizing.  The drawbacks are that the cost is fairly high, it has very questionable ingredients including poultry by-product meal and animal digest, and it is soft, thereby of little use in cleaning their teeth.  I will probably not continue with this food.  Instead, there are truly dry foods, with at least as good ingredients, that cost less and that will help with their teeth.  For treats, I'll continue with regular treats (Milkbone for example) or canned food.  This food might work for some picky small dogs.

This is an easy review:  put it in the dog dish and see what happens.  Our thin, finnicky eater would let us know.  Verdict:  once a day eater and only when hunger gobbled this down.  Now to the ultimate test:  mix with her regular dog food.  Results:  separates her old food and gobbles Chef Michael's.  Verdict:  my dog absolutely loves this.  Problem:  how can I ever go to another brand.

My littlest pup is the ultimate in picky. She likes a food for one day and hates it the next. For a while we were hand making her food with boiled veggies and meat and feeding her bite by bite on a spoon. Really! That's the only way she would eat anything.

Fortunately we found this Chef Michael food. For some reason she loves it. Some days she'll eat it right off the plate! Other days I have to go back to hand feeding her, but she still eats it without her usual protest of turning her head and hiding under the furniture. She likes it, she really likes it!

My dog is in love with this dog food. She won't even touch her other kind any longer. There are some ingredients that I'm not thrilled about on the ingredients list, but there's not much I can do about that when almost all kinds of dog food have these ingredients. The biggest thing a dog food should be is edible to a dog and my dog loves this and as I can see from other reviews, there are tons of other dogs that love it, too. If you have a picky eater, you should try this food. My dog goes straight for it, the same way she would a treat.

If my 46-lb. Golden Retriever puppy is any indication, this food tastes wonderful to dogs! She sniffed her bowl cautiously the first time we fed it to her, then eagerly wolfed it down and practically licked the bowl clean.

Since I don't plan to taste it myself, I can't say much about the flavor. The appearance is more attractive than most dry dog foods, with bits of vegetables and meats mixed together, rather than monotone brown bits that other dry foods have. Puppy doesn't particularly care what it looks like, of course.

I feel foolish even writing it, but I will say this... since we're still in the puppy phase, she still has some accidents in the house. While we were feeding her Chef Michael's food, we noticed that there was none of the normal foul odor normally associated with her bowel movements... we only discovered that she had gone by visually spotting the accident. I don't know exactly what that means, but my guess is that this food is providing better nutrition than our prior brand.

We're just about ready (per the Vet's instructions) to switch our puppy over to adult food. Chef Michael's is definitely one we will consider!

Some people may find the whole idea of the "Chef Michael" line a little over the top: Gourmet food for dogs, created by a top chef. To be honest, it isn't likely that we ever would have tried this product if I hadn't been sent a sample package for review.

Our dog is an 80 pound mixed Sharpei and Great Dane, and Chef Michael seems to be targeted more to smaller dogs; we would have to give our dog about eight cups a day, and that would get to be a much more costly proposition than his regular dry dog food, a generic brand (which we've lately started mixing with Purina Beneful, which I've reviewed separately).

Chef Michael claims to have sirloin steak flavor with potato and green bean accompaniments. In fact, it is 26% beef, and the other items are there, but the mix contains quite a bit of filler. I just don't see the need to feed the dog much in the way of filler, or for that matter to pay for it.

Certainly, the dog loves it and it serves (for us) as a great treat item rather than a mainstay of his diet. If you have a smaller dog, and don't mind the higher cost, this could be a regular meal item.

But a lot of the makeup of the product seems pitched to a human taste. The beef pieces, which are processed meat, are made up to look like little pieces of steak, complete with grill marks. That's nice, but do you think your dog will notice? Will your dog recognize the potato and green bean accompaniments as he's enjoying his meal? Our dog, frankly, just eats it. He loves it but I doubt that it's because there are faux grill marks on the beef pieces.

A comment on the packaging: it would have been nice if the package was resealable. And whoever came up with the photo on the front of the package really needs to go into another line of work. It makes the product look incredibly unappealing.

My bottom line is that this is a nice but ultimately unnecessary product. If you want to move up from generic dry dog food, try something like Purina Beneful instead. It's less expensive, less pretentious, and the dog eats it just as eagerly.

Our two dogs are not very picky eaters but when we first put this in their dishes they didn't stop until the bowls were empty; they even went to check each others bowls out to make sure they were empty. I read the ingredients list and was not too happy that there was so much "other" materials in the food.

My dogs LOVED this product.  When the product arrived they wanted in the package right now.  I found the product to be excellent quality very interesting shapes and very colorful.  I would definetly buy this product for my dogs.

I don't know about you but my husband was really impressed with the smell. But I checked it and it does smell like steak.

Small kibble mixed with a larger kibble that I'm assuming is the source of the steak smell...and possibly taste. (I didn't try it).
